#### Synthomer plc
**€350,000,000      % Senior Notes due 2029**

Synthomer plc, a public limited company incorporated under the laws of England and Wales (the “Issuer”), is offering (the “Offering”) €350,000,000 in aggregate principal
amount of its % Senior Notes due 2029 (the “Notes”). The Issuer will use the proceeds of the Offering, together with cash on balance sheet, to (i) repurchase or redeem
certain of the Issuer’s €520,000,000 3⅞% Senior Notes due 2025 (the “Existing Notes”) and (ii) pay certain costs, expenses and fees related to the Offering. The Notes will be
issued pursuant to an indenture to be dated, 2024 (the “Indenture”) among, inter alios, the Issuer and Citibank, N.A., London Branch as trustee (the “Trustee”). Interest
on the Notes will be payable semi-annually in arrears on      and of each year, commencing on     , 2024. The Notes will mature on     , 2029.

The Issuer may redeem the Notes in whole or in part at any time on or after     , 2026 at the redemption prices set out in this preliminary offering memorandum (the “Offering
**Memorandum”). Prior to     , 2026, the Issuer will be entitled to redeem, at its option, all or a portion of the Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal**
amount of the Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date, plus a “make-whole” premium, as described in
this Offering Memorandum. Prior to, 2026, the Issuer may, at its option, and on one or more occasions, also redeem up to 40 % of the original aggregate principal amount
of the Notes with the net proceeds from certain equity offerings, at the redemption price of      % of the principal amount of the Notes redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid
interest and Additional Amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date, provided that at least 60% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Notes remains
outstanding after the redemption. Additionally, the Issuer may redeem the Notes in whole, but not in part, at a price equal to their principal amount plus accrued and unpaid
interest and additional amounts, if any, upon the occurrence of certain changes in applicable tax law. Upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a change of control,
the Issuer may be required to repurchase all or any portion of the Notes at 101% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if
any, to the date of such repurchase. See “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption.” In addition, in connection with certain tender offers for the Notes, if holders of not
less than 90% in aggregate principal amount of the Notes validly tender and do not withdraw such Notes in such tender offer and the Issuer, or any third party making such a
tender offer in lieu of the Issuer, purchases all of the Notes, as applicable, validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, the Issuer or such third party will have the right
to redeem the Notes that remain outstanding in whole, but not in part, following such purchase at a price equal to the price offered to each other holder of such Notes.

The Notes will be general senior obligations of the Issuer. On the Issue Date, subject to certain material limitations pursuant to applicable laws, the Notes will be jointly and
severally guaranteed (the “Guarantees” and, each, a “Guarantee”) on a senior basis by Synthomer Holdings Limited, Synthomer Trading Limited, Synthomer (UK) Limited,
Synthomer Deutschland GmbH, Synthomer S.r.l., Synthomer Specialty Resins S.r.l., Synthomer Inc., Synthomer Sdn Bhd, Synthomer Jefferson Hills LLC, Synthomer Adhesive
Technologies LLC, Synthomer USA LLC and Synthomer LLC (the “Guarantors”). The Notes and Guarantees will rank pari passu in right of payment with any of the Issuer’s
and Guarantors’ existing and future obligations that are not expressly contractually subordinated in right of payment to the Notes or the Guarantees, as applicable, and will rank
senior in right of payment to any existing and future debt that is expressly subordinated in right of payment. The Notes and Guarantees will be effectively subordinated to any
of the Issuer’s and Guarantors’ existing and future secured obligations, to the extent of the value of such property and assets securing such debt, unless such property or assets
also secure the Notes or Guarantees, as applicable, on an equal and ratable or senior basis. The Notes and the Guarantees will be structurally subordinated to all existing and
future obligations of subsidiaries of the Issuer or such Guarantor, as applicable, that do not guarantee the Notes. Subject to certain material limitations pursuant to applicable
laws, the Guarantors also guarantee the obligations under the Existing Notes, the Revolving Credit Facility and the UKEF Facilities, in each case, on a senior basis. The validity
and enforceability of the Guarantees and the liability of each Guarantor will be subject to the limitations described in “Certain Insolvency and Enforceability Considerations.”
The Guarantees may be released in certain circumstances.

This Offering Memorandum includes information on the terms of the Notes and the Guarantees, including redemption and repurchase prices, covenants and transfer restrictions.

**NON-IFRS FINANCIAL MEASURES**

In this Offering Memorandum, we have included references to certain non-IFRS measures and ratios, including
Underlying performance, EBITDA, EBITDA Margin, capital expenditures, working capital, net debt, free cash
flow, as adjusted net borrowings (including lease liabilities), as adjusted finance costs, the ratio of as adjusted
net borrowings (including lease liabilities) to EBITDA and the ratio of EBITDA to _as adjusted finance costs._
None of these non-IFRS measures and ratios should be construed as an alternative to any IFRS measure such as
revenue, operating profit/(loss), profit/(loss) for the year or net cash flow from operating activities. References to
EBITDA in this Offering Memorandum are to Underlying EBITDA unless otherwise specified.

We define EBITDA as operating profit before depreciation, amortization and Special Items. We believe that
EBITDA provides useful information to investors about our results of operations because they are among the
measures used by our board of directors (“Board”) and management to evaluate our Underlying operating
performance, review business trends, identify strategies to improve results and make day-to-day operating
decisions, and they allow a comparison of our results across periods on a consistent basis by removing the effects
on our operating performance of our capital structure (such as the varying levels of interest expense), asset base
and capital investment cycle (such as depreciation and amortization) and items largely outside the control of
management (such as income taxes). Accordingly, such measures are reported within our annual reports and half
year reports. In addition, you should be aware that we may incur expenses similar to the adjustments in this
presentation in the future and that certain of these items could be considered recurring in nature. Our presentation
of EBITDA should not be construed as an inference that our future results will be unaffected by unusual or
irregular items. EBITDA should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for measures of our operating
performance in accordance with IFRS. Unless otherwise stated, EBITDA presented in this Offering Memorandum
is from continuing operations.


-----

We define Underlying performance as the statutory performance of Synthomer under IFRS, excluding the effect
of Special Items (as defined below).

We define capital expenditures as the purchase of property, plant and equipment, and intangible assets as recorded
on our consolidated cash flow statement.

We define net debt as total current (including bank overdrafts) and non-current borrowings, less cash and cash
equivalents.

We define working capital as inventories plus trade and other receivables less trade and other payables.

We define free cash flow as a movement in net debt before financing activities, foreign exchange and other
movement and the cash impact of Special Items, asset disposals and business combinations.

When reviewing performance, the directors and management use a combination of both IFRS and non-IFRS
(Underlying) performance measures. The Underlying performance measures provide additional information in
line with how financial performance is measured by management and reported to the Board. We believe that nonIFRS measures are a useful indicator of our ongoing operations and of our ability to service our indebtedness and
can assist certain investors, security analysts and other interested parties in evaluating us. You should exercise
caution in comparing the non-IFRS measures as reported by us to non-IFRS measures of other companies. NonIFRS measures have limitations as an analytical tool, and you should not consider them in isolation or as a
substitute for analysis of our operating results as reported under IFRS. For example, EBITDA has limitations
including the following: (i) it does not reflect our capital expenditures or capitalized development costs, our future
requirements for capital expenditures or contractual commitments; (ii) it does not reflect changes in, or cash
requirements for, our working capital needs; (iii) it does not reflect the interest expense, or the cash requirements
necessary, to service interest or principal payments on our debt; and (iv) although depreciation and amortization
are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated and amortized will often need to be replaced in the future and
EBITDA does not reflect any cash requirements that would be required for such replacements.

The discussion of financial information included in this Offering Memorandum is primarily based on our
Underlying performance, which represents our statutory performance under IFRS, excluding the effect of Special
Items (as defined below).

The definition of Special Items has been consistently applied across the periods presented in this Offering
Memorandum. Special Items are either irregular, and therefore including them in the assessment of the business’s
performance would lead to a distortion of trends, or are technical adjustments which ensure our consolidated
financial statements are in compliance with IFRS but do not reflect the operating performance of the business in
the year, or both. The following are consistently disclosed separately as Special Items in order to provide a more
clear indication of our Underlying performance:

- restructuring and site closure costs;

- sale of a business or significant asset;

- acquisition costs;

- amortization of acquired intangible assets;

- impairment of non-current assets;

- fair value adjustments in respect of derivative financial instruments where hedge accounting is not
applied;

- items of income and expense that are considered material, either by their size and/or nature;

- tax impact of above items; and

- settlement of prior period tax issues.


-----

We believe that presenting “Underlying performance” as an alternative performance measure provides additional
clarity for our investors and stakeholders on the ongoing trading performance of our businesses and it is the
primary focus of Synthomer’s narrative reporting.

The non-IFRS financial measures and ratios of Synthomer included in this Offering Memorandum are not
intended to comply with reporting requirements of the Prospectus Regulation, the UK Prospectus Regulation or
the requirements of Regulation S-X of the Securities Act, or any generally accepted accounting standards. Neither

**Overview**

We are a high-performance, highly specialized polymers and ingredients company with strong geographic
diversity and product differentiation focused on a wide range of markets through our three end-customer facing
divisions: coatings and construction; adhesives; and health and protection. Speciality chemicals are value-add
products manufactured using polymerization and other reactive processes to transform commodity raw materials
into polymers and other complex chemical outputs that are used by customers in a variety of downstream
industries including the healthcare, consumer goods and construction sectors. End products for our speciality
chemicals include, but are not limited to, medical gloves, tires and rubber modifiers, artificial turf and carpet
backing, mattresses, food packaging, coatings and adhesives. We had revenue from continuing operations of
£1,970.9 million and EBITDA of £142.1 million from continuing operations for the year ended December 31,
2023.

From January 1, 2023, we have operated through the following three divisions or reportable segments:

  - _Coatings & Construction Solutions focuses on enhancing the sustainable performance of a wide range_
of coatings and construction products, with a total addressable market of more than £9 billion covering
architectural and masonry coatings, mortar modification, waterproofing and flooring, fiber bonding, gel
foam elastomers and energy solutions. For the year ended December 31, 2023, Coatings & Construction
Solutions had revenue of £815.5 million, with EBITDA of £100.1 million and underlying operating profit
of £73.3 million from continuing operations.

  - _Adhesive Solutions focuses on the solutions needed to bond, modify and compatibilize surfaces and_
components for products including tapes and labels, packaging, hygiene, building and construction, tires
and plastic modification, with a total addressable market of approximately $12 billion, helping improve
the permeability, strength, elasticity, damping, dispersion and grip of these end products. For the year
ended December 31, 2023, Adhesive Solutions had revenue of £581.7 million, with EBITDA of £31.2
million and underlying operating loss of £7.5 million from continuing operations.

  - _Health & Protection and Performance Materials focuses on the enhancement of the protection and_
performance of goods across a wide range of industries including medical glove manufacture, speciality
paper, food packaging, carpet and artificial turf, with a total addressable market of more than £4 billion.
For the year ended December 31, 2023, Health & Protection and Performance Materials had revenue of
£573.7 million, with EBITDA of £31.0 million and underlying operating loss of £0.7 million from
continuing operations.

Up until December 31, 2022, we operated and reported through five global operational business segments:

  - _Functional Solutions. For the year ended December 31, 2022 (the last year during which we reported_
such segment), Functional Solutions had revenue of £1,001.3 million, with EBITDA of £127.8 million
and underlying operating profit of £101.1 million from continuing operations.

  - _Industrial Specialities. For the year ended December 31, 2022 (the last year during which we reported_
such segment), Industrial Specialities had revenue of £233.9 million, with EBITDA of £31.8 million and
underlying operating profit of £25.5 million from continuing operations.

1


-----

  - _Adhesive Technologies. For the year ended December 31, 2022 (the last year during which we reported_
such segment), Adhesive Technologies had revenue of £391.3 million, with EBITDA of £39.5 million
and underlying operating profit of £22.5 million from continuing operations.

  - _Performance Elastomers. For the year ended December 31, 2022 (the last year during which we reported_
such segment), Performance Elastomers had revenue of £659.7 million, with EBITDA of £49.1 million
and underlying operating profit of £19.5 million from continuing operations.

  - _Acrylate Monomers. For the year ended December 31, 2022 (the last year during which we reported such_
segment), Acrylate Monomers had revenue of £97.7 million, with EBITDA of £21.7 million and
underlying operating profit of £20.6 million from continuing operations.

As of December 31, 2023, we served over 6,000 customers through our three divisions, currently supported by
the operation of 36 manufacturing sites (with another announced closure underway) in 17 countries, including
four innovation Centers of Excellence that form part of the broader network of 12 technical centers, and
approximately 4,200 employees globally.

**Our Strengths**

We believe that the following are among our key competitive strengths:

**_Global speciality chemicals company with leading positions in our markets_**

We are a global speciality chemicals company and one of the world’s leading suppliers of water-based polymers,
with a number of our product types holding market-leading positions globally, as well as more specifically in
Europe, the United States and the Middle East. As a speciality chemicals producer, we channel our technical
expertise and customer and end-market knowledge to help our customers develop a diverse variety of end
products, including medical gloves, tires and rubber modifiers, artificial turf and carpet backing, mattresses, food
packaging, coatings, adhesives and other end products. Our long-term customer partners benefit from our
knowledge and understanding of their technical needs, our customer service and our R&D, which has allowed us
to develop innovative solutions that help our customers' business.

As of January 1, 2023, we reorganized our divisional structure along three market-focused divisions, to better
serve our end-market customers, comprised of (i) Coatings & Construction Solutions, (ii) Adhesive Solutions and
(iii) Health & Protection and Performance Materials. We consider both of the Coatings & Construction Solutions
and Adhesive Solutions divisions to constitute the core strategic growth areas of our business, while the Health &
Protection and Performance Materials division includes our NBR base business, specializing in products that are
used in the manufacture of dipped products for medical, industrial and household applications, including
protective gloves, as well as our non-core businesses. See “Business—Customers and End Markets—End
_Markets.”_

Our Coatings & Construction Solutions division brings together a range of our businesses focused on the coatings
and construction end-markets, reflecting our desire to strengthen our positioning within these markets and to
improve our portfolio through sustainability-focused innovation and customer value propositions. It is currently
our largest division in terms of both continuing revenue and EBITDA contribution and we are one of the leading
suppliers in Europe across each of our key coatings and construction product ranges.

Our Adhesive Solutions division has one of the broadest offerings of adhesive solutions products in the industry,
with leading manufacturing positions in Europe, the United States and the Middle East across all tackifier product
groups.

Our Health & Protection and Performance Materials division includes products that enhance protection and
performance in a wide range of industries. Globally, we are the second largest producer of NBR latex by volume,
which our customers use in the manufacturing of, among other things, medical gloves.

**_Attractive end markets aligned to long term growth megatrends_**

While the level of demand for each of our product types and in each of our end markets is affected by factors
specific to that product type and that particular end market, certain overarching global trends have an impact
across our product types and end markets. These include (i) accelerating urbanization resulting in migration from
urban areas to cities and an increase in infrastructure developments, (ii) demographic changes and social changes,
such as an ageing population and a growing middle class in certain emerging markets, (iii) increased focus on
climate change and sustainability, including the impact of an increasing global focus on energy reduction and
more sustainable products, which in turn increases demand for lower carbon products more circular products as
well as adaptive products for a wider variety of weather conditions and (iv) a shifting economic center of gravity
toward Asia.

We believe that these global macroeconomic trends, when combined with specific growth drivers within each of
our end markets and the nuanced strategic initiatives within each of our three divisions, contribute to the expected
growth of our business in excess of GDP.

_Coatings & Construction Solutions_

We expect both of the coating and construction end markets we serve from our Coatings & Construction Solutions
division to grow in excess of global GDP, as our focused strategy allows us to access end-markets growing in
excess of global GDP, supported by specific end-market growth drivers. Within the coating end market, we see
both an increased customer appetite for water-based coatings that replace or remove the need for harmful organic
solvents as well as revenue synergies derived from our previous acquisitions. Within the construction end market,
favorable global macroeconomic trends, such as increased urbanization and a growing middle class within urban
areas, as well as the professionalization of the construction business are driving long-term increases in demand
for our products. Further, this increase in demand is augmented by a healthy innovation pipeline of new products
to provide a wide range of solutions for our customers.

We aim to leverage these growth drivers as part of our division-wide strategy to (i) improve our geographical
balance by focusing on growing markets in Asia and the Americas, (ii) optimize our asset base and expand network
efficiency projects, (iii) improve our product portfolio through more sustainable innovation derived from our
wealth of end market experience to provide customer value and (iv) improving our cost control and capacity
management on a division-wide basis.

3


-----

_Adhesive Solutions_

We expect the adhesives end market we serve through our Adhesive Solutions division to grow in excess of global
GDP, as our focused strategy allows us to access end-markets growing in excess of global GDP, supported by as
specific end-market growth drivers. Our Adhesive Solutions division benefits from long-term relationships with
over 700 customers who sell products in more than 1000 locations throughout the world, which gives us significant
insight into the constantly evolving demands of our customers and fuels a healthy innovation pipeline of new
products to provide a wide range of solutions for our customers. In addition, we continue to derive revenue
synergies following our acquisition of the Adhesives Resins Business.

We aim to leverage these growth drivers as part of our division-wide strategy to (i) broaden our supply of raw
materials to improve asset and supply chain reliability, (ii) deliver additional production capacity through
debottlenecking projects and operational efficiency initiatives, (iii) refine our capital allocation to reprioritize
capital expenditure within the Adhesive Solutions division and (iv) improving our cost control and efficiency by
reducing working capital on a division-wide basis.

_Health & Protection and Performance Materials_

We expect the health & protection end market we serve from through our Health & Protection and Performance
Materials division to grow in excess of global GDP, as our focused strategy allows us to access end-markets
growing in excess of global GDP, supported by as specific end-market growth drivers s. Our Health & Protection
and Performance Materials division benefits from favorable global macroeconomic trends as well as focused
process improvements and disciplined investments in proprietary technology.

We aim to leverage these growth drivers with as part of our division-wide strategy to (i) continue innovating with
our processes to drive efficiency, (ii) deliver increased cost competitiveness within our Malaysian supply chain,
(iii) fostering intimate customer relationships and (iv) further divesting non-core assets from our portfolio.

**_Long standing, collaborative relationships with blue chip customer base_**

As of December 31, 2023, we have 36 manufacturing sites (with another announced closure underway) across 17
countries in the Europe, North America and Asia, resulting in a balanced geographic footprint with 49.8% of
revenues generated in Europe, 25.3% in North America, 17.4% in Asia and 7.5% in the rest of the world.

We served approximately 6,000 customers across the world in the year ended December 31, 2023, including many
global blue-chip companies. We believe we have strong and long-term customer relationships, with an average
length of 13-15 years. Our customer base is diversified and well-balanced across geographies and end markets.
For the year ended December 31, 2023, our largest customer represented approximately 3% of revenues from
continuing operations while revenues from our twenty largest customers represented approximately 24% of
revenues from continuing operations.

Some examples of key customers include: (i) with respect to Coatings & Construction Solutions, PPG Industries,
Inc., Baker Hughes, Akzo Nobel N.V., Sika AG, Proctor & Gamble Company and Haliburton Company; (ii) with
respect to Adhesive Solutions, Henkel Ltd, HB Fuller Company, Sherwin Williams Company, Pirelli & C. S.p.A.
and Continental AG; and (iii) with respect to Health & Protection and Performance Materials, Top Glove
Corporation Bhd, Sappi Limited, Riverstone Holdings Limited, Fomosa Plastics and the Condor Group.

**_Global manufacturing footprint with further simplification of asset base underway_**

We have a global manufacturing footprint utilizing state-of-the-art technology underpinned by our long-term
investment program in strategic sites. We have 36 manufacturing plans across EMEA, North America and Asia,
with 20 production facilities across Europe and the Middle East, nine production in North America and seven sites
in Asia. Given that many of our products are water-based, with approximately 50% or higher water content,
transportation and storage of these products can be costly due to the size and weight of water-based products as
well as the hazards inherent in transporting and storing chemicals. We therefore benefit from our asset base being
located in close proximity to many of our customers.

Our asset base enables us to optimize production across our facilities, such as transferring products from one plant
to another to better match customer requirements, without the need to invest in significant capital expenditure. In

4


-----

recent years we have invested capital expenditure into growth projects intended to expand and enhance our
production capabilities and make our processes more efficient. For example, in January 2024, in order to bolster
our supply chain, increase reliability and improve our cost position for hydrocarbon resin production in Europe,
we purchased certain raw material production assets from Arakawa, which will be managed under contract at the
Dow ValuePark in Germany. In addition, through non-core divestments and rationalization, including the decision
to mothball our NBR facility in Kluang, Malaysia, which is expected to reduce our NBR production capacity by
approximately 20%, and support better utilization levels across the Group, we are focusing on reducing
complexity and optimizing our site footprint under our strategy to “Focus, Strengthen and Grow”.

**_Impressive track record of new product innovation through sustainability and customer focused R&D_**

We have an impressive track record and pipeline of new product development through customer-focused R&D
which supports our strong cash profile. We maintain four Centers of Excellence as part of an innovation network
comprising 12 sites. Our four Centers of Excellence include sites in Germany and the U.S., as well as our industryleading Asia Innovation Centre and our state-of-the-art U.K. Innovation Centre established in 2019. In 2024, we
broke ground on a new innovation center in Shanghai, China, designed to support our customers. The China
Innovation Center will focus on the development of products that meet new environmental requirements,
including high-performance adhesives for lithium batteries for electric vehicles and energy storage, water-based
coatings and adhesives, and plastic modification and recycling. For the year ended December 31, 2023, we
invested £34 million in R&D and launched 14 new products. These investments in R&D continue to have a
significant effect on our revenues, with 22% of our sales volume for the year ended December 31, 2023 derived
from products that we developed in the previous five years or are protected by patent or other intellectual property
protections. We currently employ approximately 380 professionals in R&D-focused roles.

An increasing focus on sustainability is a key trend that, we believe, will increase customer demand as regulation
is driving the requirement for lower-carbon, bio-based and circular products. Our portfolio is positioned to help
drive circular solutions (for example, recyclable packaging) and our high-performance water-based polymers can
displace solvent-borne polymers, leading to further demand for the our products. As a recognized leader in waterbased and emission reducing polymers, this creates a huge opportunity for us. Our “Vision 2030” plan is a longterm, embedded part of our business strategy, which we expect to be a value driver and a key principle in our
responsible approach to doing business. Our “Vision 2030” plan includes targets for the areas where we can have
the most material impact, including:

  - at least 60% of new products having enhanced sustainability benefits by 2030 (64% as of December 31,
2023);

  - reducing Scope 1 and 2 absolute greenhouse gas emissions by 47% relative to 2019 baseline levels, which
have been adjusted to take account of the acquisition of the Adhesives Resins Business (42% reduction
as of December 31, 2023);

  - reducing Scope 3 absolute greenhouse gas emissions by 28% relative to 2019 baseline levels, which have
been adjusted to take account of the acquisition of the Adhesives Resins Business (14% reduction as of
December 31, 2023); and

  - at least 40% women in senior management roles (30% as of December 31, 2023).

We have a long track record of helping customers towards their own sustainability goals. Our emission-reducing
solutions and lower-carbon intensity operations all make a positive contribution towards customers’ Scope 3
carbon footprints. Our capabilities and products can help customers in multiple areas, whether that is replacing
solvent-based coatings with water-based alternatives, developing water-based polymers and re-dispersible
powders for construction customers, or innovating bio-based, low-carbon footprint and circular solutions for
adhesives.

**_Clear direction to increase specialization, grow global position and streamline operations_**

We have developed a well-balanced and diversified portfolio through a combination of organic and inorganic
growth and a continued repositioning towards specialty and complex formulations, supported by our robust R&D
activity, which helps to make our revenue more resilient to negative fluctuations in the demand for any particular

5


-----

product or from any specific customer or geography. As we grow and capitalize on the underlying macroeconomic
trends in the speciality chemical industry, we have a clear path to increasing our product mix towards speciality
chemicals as we balance the geographic distribution of our end markets and streamline operations. A diverse
portfolio lends itself toward an increasing focus on high-value specialty chemical products for attractive and
resilient niche markets characterized by growth in excess of GDP.

Over the past year, we have increased our proportion of speciality chemicals from roughly 50% of our production
in 2022 to approximately 55% in 2023, as we look to drive this percentage higher toward 70% speciality chemical
weighting in the future. Our focus on the key value drivers for the speciality chemical market, including high
customer intimacy, value-based pricing, application innovation and flexibility in production in logistics, provides
a clear path to achieve this weighting.

Further, we aim to balance our geographic revenue distribution between EMEA, the United States and Asia. We
derived approximately half of our revenues in 2023 from EMEA, with the remaining half split between the United
States and Asia. As we seek to optimize our geographic footprint, we intend to increase our presence in the United
States while maintaining our presence in Asia, such that approximately 40% of our revenues are from EMEA,
approximately 35% from the United States and the remaining quarter from Asia. The following figure illustrates
our evolving geographic footprint, speciality chemical weighting and number of sites:

We aim to accomplish this geographic rebalancing while we streamline our operations, such that we move from
more than 40 sites in 2022 to less than 30 sites in strategic locations in the future.

**_Experienced management team with impressive track record_**

Our senior management team has strong industry experience with a demonstrated track record of achieving
profitable growth in the speciality chemical industry, successfully managing business portfolios through
acquisitions and divestments, disciplined capital investment plans and optimizing our fixed cost base. Michael
Willome, our chief executive officer, has led us since November 2021 after previously having served as chief
executive officer of another public global industrial company. Following the key acquisitions of OMNOVA in
2020 and the Adhesive Resins Business in 2022, our management team has effectively integrated these
acquisitions and we have been able to achieve synergies above initial projections in both acquired businesses.
Our management team has extensive experience in the speciality chemical industry, including working for leading
companies such as Conzzeta AG, Essentra plc, Chemtura, GE Speciality Chemicals and Clariant, and a proven
ability to increase productivity, reduce costs and control capital expenditures and working capital. We believe the
experience of our management team is a distinct competitive advantage. In addition, our senior management team
has demonstrated the ability to streamline our businesses by focusing on core competencies and divest of noncore businesses, as evidenced by the divestment of the Laminates, Films and Coated Fabrics Businesses in
February 2023. The divestment of non-core businesses has enabled us to focus management time on core
activities, reduce our capital expenditure requirements going forward and also reduce our exposure to
underperforming cash consuming businesses.

6


-----

**_Well-established financial policy with clear plan underway to further deleverage._**

We aim to maintain a conservative and sustainable capital management strategy with clear policies with respect
to our balance sheet leverage, and investments and shareholder returns in order to maintain an efficient and flexible
capital structure over a longer term. We take a disciplined approach to investment opportunities including mergers
and acquisitions and growth capital expenditure.

While our ambition historically has been to maintain a net leverage to EBITDA ratio, on an ongoing basis, of
approximately 1.0–2.0x, which we view as sustainable, our leverage is currently at higher than average levels,
due primarily to historically low NBR prices and demand as a result of destocking following the COVID-19
pandemic, combined with increased debt taken on to finance the acquisition of the Adhesive Resins Business.

We have responded to this challenge and in October 2023, completed a £276 million rights issue (net proceeds of
£266 million), demonstrating our commitment to reducing our leverage alongside other targeted actions,
including:

  - _Dividend suspension: In October 2022, we announced the suspension of all dividends for the year ended_
December 31, 2023 and an ongoing suspension until our net leverage is at least below 3.0x.

  - _Non-core divestment: The divestment of our Laminates, Films and Coated Fabrics Business on February_
28, 2023 raised net cash proceeds of $262 million (with a further $5 million receivable in cash on the
13-month anniversary of completion), while supporting our ongoing drive to increase the speciality
weighting of the Group. Our non-core portfolio rationalization program remains ongoing, with three
further formal divestment processes currently underway.

  - _Cost savings: We reduced our capital expenditures in 2023 to £84 million (£91 million in 2022) and have_
deployed a discretionary cost-savings program that successfully saved the Group £18 million in 2023,
further targeting savings of £30-40 million annually from our new procurement program and
approximately £20 million from our Adhesive Solutions program over 2024 and 2025.

  - _Working capital improvements: We identified opportunities to optimize working capital, in particular for_
our Adhesives Solutions business, with an overall reduction in inventory of £46 million in 2023. In
addition, we instituted a receivables financing program, with a £27.9 million increase in receivables
financing to £110.6 million.

**Our Strategy**

Our growth strategy is driven by global megatrends and we are focused on driving sustainable growth through
business efficiency, R&D and capital investment projects. Our strategy is composed of the following key pillars:

**_Organic growth in attractive end markets_**

Our core strategic growth markets, comprising coatings, construction, adhesives, and health and protection, each
benefit from robust sectoral growth dynamics in excess of baseline GDP. These markets are driven by accelerating
global megatrends including accelerating urbanization, demographic and social change, climate change and
sustainability and shifting economic power. In October 2022, as part of its new strategy, we announced a new
divisional organizational structure aligning our organization with our core end-markets. This alignment of
operational segments and end-markets is expected to assist us in anticipating and meeting customers’ needs at
pace and deliver better products with improved margin and product differentiation.

Innovation and more sustainable products, such as water-based solutions displacing solvents in the construction,
coatings and adhesives markets, are key drivers of growth across the Group’s core markets and developing
products through focused customer-centric R&D is a key component of the Group’s strategy. For the year ended
December 31, 2023, 22% of our sales volumes were derived from products that we launched in the previous five
years or are protected by patent or other intellectual property protections. In the year ended December 31, 2023,
we launched 14 new products across multiple application areas.

7


-----

**_Rigorous and consistent portfolio management to build focused, leading positions_**

As part of focusing the business, we intend to increase the weighting of speciality chemicals versus base chemicals
in our portfolio, create a more balanced geographic footprint, streamline our operations and apply more efficient
capital allocation across our businesses. During our strategic review in 2022, we identified our core markets,
which combine the most attractive growth prospects and where we are most differentiated. We are focusing our
resources on these segments and our new divisional structure enables differentiated steering in the allocation of
financial and operational resources in line with this strategy.

In addition, we identified a number of non-core businesses which have limited synergies with the rest our
identified growth platforms and which are less attractive areas for us to deploy capital. In line with our strategy,
on February 28, 2023, we completed the divestment of the Laminates, Films and Coated Fabrics Businesses.
Moving forward, we will continue to assess our strategic position in terms of disposing of non-core businesses to
rationalize our portfolio, reduce complexity and increase our focus on attractive end-markets and speciality
products.

Our divisional structure enables a differentiated steering of the allocation of financial and operational resources,
including capital allocation. We aim to allocate approximately 75% of our capital to the Coatings & Construction
Solutions and Adhesive Solutions divisions and approximately 25% to the Health & Protection and Performance
Materials division over the medium-term.

While our primary focus is on furthering our non-core divestment program, alongside this we are actively
considering a number of low-capital growth opportunities, such as potential partnerships. We are also identifying
potential accretive bolt-on acquisition opportunities in strategically attractive end markets and geographies for the
future, when our financial circumstances allow.

**_Operational and commercial excellence in how we run our business_**

We are focused on continuous improvement across our operations to advance production efficiency, sales
effectiveness and functional excellence while remaining committed to our sustainability standards. To achieve
these aims, we seek to identify good practice in all areas of the business and ensure that relevant learnings are
disseminated across the business.

We aim to drive profitability through maximizing the utilization of our assets. To achieve this, we focus on
identifying the root causes of production bottlenecks and finding innovative solutions. For example, a project at
our Longview site in Texas will debottleneck production and is expected to increase capacity by 10% to take
advantage of growth in the amorphous polyolefin market in North America.

For decades, we have been a world leading supplier of water-based polymers that avoid the use of solvents and
keep harmful VOCs out of the atmosphere. We have also become a global innovator in driving the use of waterbased technology. Over the last few years, we have worked to embed environmental sustainability into our
products and operations while remaining committed to driving efficiency. Sustainability now plays a major role
in our innovation agenda for customers, as well as our ongoing work to address our own greenhouse gas emission
footprint, as measured by our _“Vision 2030” roadmap and near-term milestone targets, as overseen by the_
Executive Sustainability Steering Committee established in 2022.

**_Diversity, equity and inclusion and holistic people development_**

Across all of our businesses, our employees execute our strategy and deliver for all stakeholders and we continue
to develop them to be prepared for the opportunities and challenges that lie ahead. To support this, we are
implementing four strategic employee priorities: (i) promoting holistic people development; (ii) strengthening our
leadership capability; (iii) embracing Synthomer excellence; and (iv) establishing an innovative workplace
culture.

**Recent Developments**

**_The Tender Offer_**

On April 9, 2024, we announced a tender offer (the “Tender Offer”) to purchase at par for cash consideration up
to €370.0 million of our Existing Notes, held in the relevant Regulation S global note by non-U.S. holders outside
the United States, validly tendered and accepted for purchase pursuant to the Tender Offer (the “Maximum
**Acceptance Amount”). The Tender Offer is expected to expire at 4:00 p.m., London time, on April 16, 2024 and**
settlement is expected to take place on April 19, 2024, conditional on, among other things, the closing of the
Offering. The Issuer reserves the right, subject to applicable law, to (i) waive any and all conditions to the Tender
Offer, (ii) extend or terminate the Tender Offer, (iii) increase the Maximum Acceptance Amount or (iv) otherwise
amend the Tender Offer in any respect, in each case, without offering revocation rights to holders of the Existing
Notes. In the event that the aggregate principal amount of Existing Notes tendered and accepted for purchase
pursuant to the Tender Offer is less than the Maximum Acceptance Amount, the Issuer intends to redeem a portion
of the Existing Notes equal to the difference between such tendered amount and the Maximum Acceptance
Amount. The Issuer intends to effect such redemption at par following July 1, 2024.

This Offering Memorandum does not constitute an offer to purchase the Existing Notes. The Tender Offer will be
made pursuant to a separate tender offer memorandum (the “Offer to Purchase”) and not pursuant to this Offering
Memorandum. It is expected that the offering of Notes will price before the Tender Offer expires. Accordingly,
the results of the Tender Offer will not be known at the time of pricing of the Notes, and neither the pricing nor
the closing of the offering of the Notes is conditioned upon the consummation of the Tender Offer at any minimum
level of acceptance. The Offer to Purchase, and not this Offering Memorandum, sets out the terms of the Tender
Offer and the procedures for noteholders to tender any Existing Notes. Neither the Offer to Purchase nor any part
thereof is incorporated by reference in, or forms part of, this Offering Memorandum.

See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Existing Notes.” An amount up to €370.0 million of the Existing Notes is
expected to be validly tendered and accepted for purchase pursuant to the Tender Offer.

(6) On March 20, 2023, the Issuer, as borrower, and certain of its subsidiaries entered into the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, which
provided for the Revolving Credit Facility. On September 5, 2023, we entered into an amendment and restatement agreement in relation
to the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement extending the termination date of the Revolving Credit Facility from May 31, 2025 to July
31, 2027, and reducing the total commitments to $400 million. On March 6, 2024, we further amended the Revolving Credit Facility
Agreement, reducing the total commitments to €300 million. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Revolving Credit Facility
was undrawn.

11


-----

(7) On October 10, 2022, the Issuer, as borrower, and certain of its subsidiaries entered into the UKEF Facilities Agreement, which provides
for unsecured euro term facilities in an aggregate amount of €287.5 million (the “Euro **UKEF Facilities”) and unsecured dollar term**
loan facilities in an aggregate amount of $230 million (the “Dollar **UKEF Facilities” and, together with Euro UKEF Facilities, the**
“UKEF Facilities”). The UKEF Facilities mature on October 11, 2027 and are available for drawing until the earlier of October 10,
2024 or the date that the facility is drawn in full. As of December 31, 2023, the UKEF Facilities were fully drawn.

(8) The Notes will be general senior obligations of the Issuer. On the Issue Date, subject to certain material limitations pursuant to applicable
laws, the Notes will be jointly and severally guaranteed on a senior basis by Synthomer Holdings Limited, Synthomer Trading Limited,
Synthomer (UK) Limited, Synthomer Deutschland GmbH, Synthomer S.r.l., Synthomer Specialty Resins S.r.l., Synthomer Inc.,
Synthomer Sdn Bhd, Synthomer Jefferson Hills LLC, Synthomer Adhesive Technologies LLC, Synthomer USA LLC and Synthomer
LLC. Subject to certain material limitations pursuant to applicable laws, the Guarantors also guarantee the obligations under the Existing
Notes, the Revolving Credit Facility and the UKEF Facilities, in each case, on a senior basis. For the year ended December 31, 2023,
the Guarantors generated 65.2% of our EBITDA.

(9) Synthomer Jefferson Hills LLC and Synthomer Adhesive Technologies LLC were originally Eastman operating companies. Following
completion of the acquisition of the Adhesives Resins Business on April 1, 2022, Synthomer Jefferson Hills LLC and Synthomer
Adhesive Technologies LLC became wholly owned subsidiaries of Synthomer Inc. (at such time, known as OMNOVA Solutions Inc.)
and both entities are Guarantors under the Notes.

(10) Not all of our subsidiaries will guarantee the Notes. As of December 31, 2023, the total borrowings of our non-Guarantor subsidiaries,

on a pro forma basis, after giving effect to the Offering, including the application of the net proceeds therefrom, and the use of proceeds
therefrom as described under “Use of Proceeds,” were nil. The Notes will be structurally subordinated to the liabilities of the nonGuarantor subsidiaries. In the event of a bankruptcy, liquidation or reorganization of any of these non-guarantor subsidiaries, the nonguarantor subsidiaries will pay the holders of their debt and their trade creditors before they will be able to distribute any of their assets
to the Issuer. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Notes and Guarantees—The Notes and the Guarantees are structurally
_subordinated to the indebtedness and other obligations of our non-guarantor subsidiaries.”_

(11) As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Issuer is party to certain joint ventures and holds a minority stake in certain entities.

These entities are not in the Restricted Group and are thus not subject to the covenants contained in the Indenture. See “Description of
_the Notes.”_

**Optional Redemption ...................** At any time prior to, 2026, we may redeem up to 40% of the
aggregate principal amount of the Notes using the net cash proceeds of
certain equity offerings, at the redemption price of      % of the
principal amount of the Notes redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid
interest and Additional Amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the
redemption date, provided that at least 60% of the original aggregate
principal amount of the Notes remains outstanding after the redemption.
See “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption.”

At any time prior to, 2026, we may redeem some or all of
the Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount
of the Notes redeemed, plus, in each case, accrued and unpaid interest
and Additional Amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the applicable
redemption date plus the applicable “make whole” premium. See
“Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption.”

At any time on or after, 2026, we may redeem some or all
of the Notes at the redemption prices set forth in “Description of the
_Notes—Optional Redemption.”_

In connection with certain tender offers for the Notes, if holders of not
less than 90% in aggregate principal amount of the Notes validly tender
and do not withdraw such Notes in such tender offer and the Issuer, or
any third party making such a tender offer in lieu of the Issuer, purchases
all of the Notes, as applicable, validly tendered and not withdrawn by
such holders, the Issuer or such third party will have the right to redeem
the Notes that remain outstanding in whole, but not in part, following
such purchase at a price equal to the price offered to each other holder
of such Notes.

**Optional Tax Redemption ...........** If, as a result of certain changes or amendments in the tax laws of any
Relevant Taxing Jurisdiction (as defined in the Description of the Notes)
the Issuer or any Guarantor is or would on the next payment date be
required to pay any Additional Amounts (as defined in the Description
of the Notes), the Issuer may redeem the Notes in whole, but not in part,
at any time, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount, plus
accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any, to the date
of redemption. See “Description of the Notes—Redemption Upon
_Changes in Withholding Taxes.”_

**Additional Amounts .....................** Any payments made by the Issuer or any Guarantor under or with respect
to the Notes or any Guarantee will be made without withholding or
deduction for taxes, unless required by law. If withholding or deduction
for such taxes imposed or levied by any Relevant Taxing Jurisdiction (as

received after such withholding or deduction is not less than the amount
that would have been received in the absence of such withholding or
deduction. See “Description of the Notes—Additional Amounts.”

(as defined for purposes of the Notes), holders of the Notes will have the
right to require the Issuer to repurchase all or part of the Notes at a
purchase price in cash equal to 101% of the aggregate principal amount
of the Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts,
if any, to, but excluding, the purchase date. See “Description of the
_Notes—Certain Covenants—Change of Control.”_

among other things, limit our ability and the ability of our Restricted
Subsidiaries (as defined therein) to, among other things:

                            - incur additional debt;

                            - create liens;

                            - pay dividends, redeem capital stock or make certain other
restricted payments or investments;

                            - enter into agreements that restrict dividends from restricted
subsidiaries;

                            - sell assets, including capital stock of restricted subsidiaries;

                            - engage in transactions with affiliates; and

                            - effect a consolidation or merger.

These covenants are subject to a number of important qualifications and
exceptions and certain of them will be suspended if and when, and for
so long as, the Notes are rated investment grade. For more details see
“Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants.”

**Transfer Restrictions ....................** The Notes and the Guarantees have not been, and will not be, registered
under the Securities Act or the securities laws of any other jurisdiction
and may not be offered or sold, except pursuant to an exemption from,
or in a transaction not subject to, the registration requirements of the
Securities Act. We have not agreed to, or otherwise undertaken to,
register the Notes (including by way of an exchange offer).

**No Established Market .................** The Notes will be new securities for which there is currently no
established trading market. Although the Initial Purchasers have
informed us that they intend to make a market in the Notes, they are not
obligated to do so and they may discontinue market-making at any time
without notice. Accordingly, we cannot assure you that a liquid market
for the Notes will develop or be maintained.

to be listed and admitted to trading on the ISM. There can be no
assurance that the Notes will be listed on the London Stock Exchange,
that such permission to deal in the Notes will be granted or that such
listing will be maintained.

(5) We define EBITDA as operating profit before depreciation, amortization and Special Items. See “Presentation of Financial and Other
_Data” for the definition of Special Items and footnote (A) below for a breakdown of Special Items for the relevant periods. We believe_
that EBITDA provides useful information to investors about our results of operations because it is among the measures used by our
Board and management to evaluate our Underlying operating performance, review business trends, identify strategies to improve results
and make day-to-day operating decisions, and it allows a comparison of our results across periods on a consistent basis by removing the
effects on our operating performance of our capital structure (such as the varying levels of interest expense), asset base and capital
investment cycle (such as depreciation and amortization) and items largely outside the control of management (such as income taxes).
In addition, you should be aware that we may incur expenses similar to the adjustments in this presentation in the future and that certain
of these items could be considered recurring in nature. Our presentation of EBITDA should not be construed as an inference that our
future results will be unaffected by unusual or irregular items. EBITDA should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for
measures of our operating performance in accordance with IFRS. The Underlying performance measures, including EBITDA, provide
additional information in line with how financial performance is measured by management and reported to the Board. We believe that
these non-IFRS measures are a useful indicator of our ongoing performance and our ability to service our indebtedness and can assist
certain investors, security analysts and other interested parties in evaluating us. You should exercise caution in comparing the non-IFRS
measures as reported by us to non-IFRS measures of other companies. Non-IFRS measures have limitations as an analytical tool, and
you should not consider them in isolation. For example, with respect to EBITDA, some of these limitations include the following: (i) it
does not reflect our capital expenditures, our future requirements for capital expenditures or contractual commitments; (ii) it does not
reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs; (iii) it does not reflect the interest expense, or the cash
requirements necessary, to service interest or principal payments on our debt; and (iv) although depreciation and amortization are noncash charges, the assets being depreciated and amortized will often need to be replaced in the future and EBITDA does not reflect any
cash requirements that would be required for such replacements. For the year ended December 31, 2023, EBITDA adjusted to exclude
the impact of IFRS 16 would have been £129.5 million.
