**OFF BALANCE SHEET ARRANGEMENTS AND CONTINGENT LIABILITIES**

On December, 15 2022, Synthomer Deutschland GmbH as German originator and OMNOVA and Synthomer
Adhesive Technologies LLC as US originators entered into the Factoring Agreements, pursuant to which the
purchaser made available the factoring facilities (the “Factoring Facilities”). On June 27, 2023, the Factoring
Facilities were amended to include Synthomer Trading Ltd, Synthomer (UK) and Synthomer Middelburg BV as
originators, and on December 15, 2023, the Factoring Facilities were further amended to include Synthomer USA
LLC as an originator. In addition, we had contracted capital expenditure commitments of £8.8 million as of
December 31, 2023.

As mentioned below under “—Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure on Market Risk—Foreign Currency Risk,”
we have a policy of hedging all significant foreign exchange transactional exposure at the operating company
level. We borrow a proportion of our funding in overseas currencies to hedge the net assets held in those
currencies.

**QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE DISCLOSURE ON MARKET RISK**

We are, in the normal course of business, exposed to a variety of financial risks, including market risks and interest
rate risks. For additional information, see Note 22 (Financial instruments) of the 2023 Consolidated Financial
Statements, included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

**_Foreign Currency Risk_**

A significant proportion of our revenue and assets are in currencies other than pound sterling and fluctuations in
currency exchange rates may significantly impact our results. We have a policy of hedging all significant foreign
exchange transactional exposure at operating company level and borrow a proportion of our funding in overseas
currencies to hedge the net assets held in those currencies.

**_Liquidity Risk_**

Our balance sheet and cash flow position, and credit market conditions and credit ratings, may restrict our ability
to obtain credit facilities or to refinance existing debt facilities in the longer term. We closely monitor our
operating cash flow and capital expenditure on a monthly basis and regularly reviews covenant compliance.

**_Pension Funding Risk_**

We have funding risks relating to defined benefit pension scheme obligations, the value of which are dependent
on volatile financial markets. The UK scheme was closed to future accrual in 2009 and additional contributions
and careful asset management should reduce the deficit over the longer term. The timescale will be affected by
movements in the financial markets and the discount rate.

**_Interest rate risk_**

We finance our operations through a mixture of retained profits and bank borrowings. We monitor interest rate
trends regularly, through discussion with our banks, and fix interest rates when it is prudent to do so. The following
table illustrates the effect on the consolidated income statement and items that are recognized directly in equity

**INDUSTRY OVERVIEW**

**Our Industry Overview**

We operate at the speciality chemicals stage in the chemicals value chain, which involves taking raw material
inputs and building complex chemical outputs utilized by customers in a variety of end products and downstream
industries.

Since January 2023, our new divisional structure increases our end market orientation, as indicated below.

_Source: Company information_

The growth drivers of each of our product types across end markets and geographic regions are supported by mega
trends including: (i) accelerating urbanization resulting in migration from urban areas to cities and an increase in
infrastructure developments, (ii) demographic changes and social changes, such as an ageing population and a
growing middle class in certain emerging markets, (iii) increased focus on climate change and sustainability,
including the impact of an increasing global focus on energy reduction and more sustainable products, which in
turn increases demand for lower carbon products more circular products as well as adaptive products for a wider
variety of weather conditions, and (iv) a shifting economic center of gravity toward Asia. Due to our balanced
product mix and our global asset footprint, with exposure to both emerging and developed markets, we are well
placed to capture market growth.

**End Markets, Market Share and Outlook for Our Divisions**

We benefit from providing goods to a diverse range of end markets. For the year ended December 31, 2023, 30%
of our sales went to Adhesives, 18% to coatings, 10% to consumer materials, 9% to construction, 8% to health &
protection, 8% to paper and carpet, 5% to energy solutions and 12% to other performance materials. The following
paragraphs provide further details into our end markets, market shares and our divisions.

**_Coatings and Construction Solutions (Aqueous – acrylic and vinylic – dispersions)_**

Dispersion products are sold predominantly to paint and coatings manufacturers and formulators of adhesives and
construction products (such as sealants, fillers and caulks) with exposure to globally growing market segments.
Strong application know-how is required to support this commercial offering.

86


-----

There are continued significant regulatory drivers that support water-based technologies across end markets, since
water-based products tend to have lower levels of Volatile Organic Compounds (“VOCs”) than solvent-based
products. There is a general trend in the industry towards producing more sustainable products including the
elimination of VOCs from coatings and adhesives formulations, since VOCs can contribute to climate change and
have unfavorable toxicological and odor characteristics. Acrylic, styrene-acrylic and vinyl dispersions contain
significantly lower levels of VOCs than solvent borne coatings formulations.

Our range of acrylic dispersions includes products for use in emulsion surface coatings, primers, interior and
exterior wood varnishes, floor paints and roof coatings.

Our range of styrene-acrylic dispersions is focused on products for use in interior and exterior emulsion paints
and roof coatings and also has applications in packaging adhesives. Our range of vinyl acetate dispersions includes
products for applications in interior and exterior emulsion coatings and adhesives for packaging, tiles & wood and
sealants for construction applications.

The European dispersions competitive landscape is fragmented, and according to Kline, we have the secondlargest market share in Europe and the Middle East for acrylic and vinylic dispersions, with approximately 13%
of the market as of March, 2024. Our largest competitors, BASF and Dow, have approximately 18% and 8%
respectively. The global market for coatings and construction is estimated to grow at a CAGR of approximately
3% per annum from 2022 to 2026.

The outlook for demand in Europe and North America is positive and growing with environmental regulations
driving an industry shift toward water-based products, which further strengthens their underlying growth trends.
In Southeast Asia, the market growth forecast remains strong, while the Middle East construction sector remains
subdued.

This sector is characterized by innovation and the development of bespoke solutions for customers with products
specified for particular use. Given the bespoke nature of many of our customers specialty products, we benefit
from long-standing customer relationships as customers face high costs for switching suppliers.

**_Adhesive Solutions (Tackifying resins and additives for adhesive products)_**

With 6 manufacturing sites across North America, Europe and Asia, along with access to additional sites hosted
by other Synthomer divisions, to service our emulsion polymers customers, we have leading market positions
(first and second in EMEA and the Americas, respectively) in an addressable market of approximately $12 billion.
With the acquisition of the Adhesives Resins Business, we now have a differentiated and diversified platform
with strong R&D and technical capabilities and a large and growing portfolio of products in hygiene, packaging
and high-performance tire additives.

87


-----

Innovation is supporting extra growth and price differentiation in attractive end markets with resilient and GDP+
growth fundamentals.

_Source: Company Filings_

Tackifying resins are key adhesive components providing sticky properties made from hydrocarbons or pine
chemicals mixed with polymers for hot melt adhesives used in hygiene adhesives, packaging, rubber and tapes
and labels. The global tackifying resins market is estimated to be approximately 3.1 megatonnes, of which
approximately 62% consists of hydrocarbon resins. Hydrocarbon based tackifiers are seeing an increased market
share in specific applications due to pricing, stability.

Pure Monomer Resins (“PMRs”) are mainly used for adhesives in packaging and book binding due to their tack
properties, but are also used in thermoplastic elastomer (TPE) over-molding and tires. PMRs are used as an
additive in tire treads to improve performance, and demand for high-performance tires is growing as governments
impose more stringent performance regulations. Overall, the growth rate of the global market for PMRs is
expected to be a CAGR of approximately 2% per annum from 2022 to 2027.

Specialty rosin resins are natural tackifying resins with a wide range of characteristics used to provide stickiness
to the final product, with main end markets being adhesives, inks, pavement marking, chewing gum, synthetic
rubbers and tires. Overall, the growth rate of the global market for specialty rosins is expected to be a CAGR of
approximately 3% per annum from 2022 to 2027.

Amorphous polyolefins (“APOs”) have three main applications: hot melt adhesives (packaging, hygiene, building
and construction and automotive end markets), rheology modification (bitumen roofing and road markings) and
sealing (windows and cables used in construction). APO demand was estimated by us to be approximately 150
kilotonnes in 2023, with hygiene being the largest segment and expected to grow the fastest. Overall, the growth
rate of the global market for APOs is expected to be a CAGR of approximately 5% per annum from 2022 to 2027.

The overall market demand for adhesive solutions is estimated to grow at a CAGR above GDP in the medium
term.

**_Health & Protection_**

_Nitrile Butadiene Rubber (NBR)_

Nitrile Butadiene Rubber (“NBR”) products are used in the manufacture of dipped products for medical, industrial
and household applications, the largest being protective gloves. We offer a range of NBR products for use in the
manufacture of thin-walled gloves for medical and laboratory use and heavy-duty gloves for household and
industrial applications. NBR latex products are sold globally to gloves manufacturers, including both large
diversified medical and consumer goods companies and smaller niche manufacturers.

88


-----

NBR competes with Polyvinyl Chloride (“PVC”) and natural rubber in this market. The potential for natural
rubber to cause allergies due to a naturally occurring protein among some glove wearers is leading to increased
substitution by NBR. NBR is expected to continue to gain share over PVC and natural rubber with estimated
CAGR of more than 6% over the coming years. Southeast Asia will remain the hub for gloves with over 80% of
global production and major investments in manufacturing capacity, even with Europe and North America
investments accelerating supported by government incentives to secure local supply.

NBR was the leading synthetic latex polymer used in Southeast Asia in 2023, representing 45% of the market by
volume, followed by styrene acrylics (dispersions) and pure acrylics (dispersions) at 17% and 11%, respectively.

We have developed innovative self-cross linking nitrile latex that eliminates the need for accelerators, which
improves the benefit and reduces any risk in use for glove wearers. In 2023 the Group recently developed and
commercialized the Group’s patented SyNovus™ Plus alternative to conventional NBR latex for nitrile gloves,
which provides medical glove makers with the same high performance barrier protection while being recyclable
and reducing GHG emissions.

We have the second-largest market share globally, with approximately 15% market share as of 2023. Our largest
competitors are Kumho Petrochemicals, LG and Nantex, which had 24%, 12% and 9%, respectively, of the global
market as of 2023. NBR market growth from 2010 to 2020 averaged greater than 8% per annum due to superior
chemistry and performance compared to natural latex and PVC.

The exceptional global demand for NBR gloves during the COVID-19 pandemic resulted in a record performance
for NBR in 2021. After 2021, destocking of nitrile gloves caused substantial softening of demand, resulting in
lower NBR volumes in 2022, while China became a significant producer of gloves and NBR, resulting in
additional oversupply. While underlying end-customer demand for medical gloves remains similar to pre-COVID
levels and we see favorable growth trends in the medium term, the destocking impact was still persistent in 2023.

However, the outlook for underlying demand remains in line with strong growth due to the hygiene megatrend
and growth in use of emerging markets, with growth forecast to more than 6% per annum. The business is wellpositioned to capture this long-term opportunity.

Our goal is to grow sales into higher margin customer segments by offering best in class technical support,
leveraging long term contracts and investing in innovation, with the Asia Innovation Center (the “AIC”) as the
center of excellence for global glove innovation.

_Styrene Butadiene Rubber (SBR)_

Styrene Butadiene Rubber (“SBR”) is sold primarily to the speciality segments of the paper, construction, textile
and floor coverings markets, as well as adhesives and foams.

In coated paper applications, the addition of a latex coating contributes to the quality of the end product by
providing gloss, smoothness, fiber coverage, stiffness and brightness for various types of paper and board.
Furthermore, latex assists the processability and/or runability of the coating color. SBR is the dominant binder in
the paper industry.

In construction applications, SBR is used as an additive in cement and asphalt to improve tensile strength and
ductility and enhance resistance to water and other solvents, thereby prolonging the useful life of the asphalt or
cement.

In textile applications, SBR is used as a binder for non-woven fabrics such as those used in filters, wipes and
home furnishings. SBR provides the fabric with added softness, stiffness and strength. In addition, SBR is used
in upholstery back-coatings to improve shape and strength.

In the floor coverings market, SBR is widely used in the back-coating of carpets where the latex acts as an adhesive
for a secondary backing, holding the fibers in place and giving stability and strength to the carpet. Products for
the carpet industry are sold both directly to carpet manufacturers (a large number of which are located within the
Benelux region) and to intermediaries who provide ready-to-use blends to smaller customers.

89


-----

Latex foam is mainly used in mattresses, pillows and manifold cushioning materials, with the entire spectrum of this
varied product largely addressed through the use of different high solid SBR grades (HS-SBR latex), in order to
apply different degrees of firmness and elasticity to these products to suit consumer’s needs. Other applications
include uses in footwear, such as for inner soles.

The market growth for SBR approximately reflects growth in GDP, with uses in particular end markets reflecting
the growth of those end markets. SBR uses in paper latex markets have declined by approximately 1% to 4% per
annum since 2010, as consumers shift from paper-based to electronic media. This has been partly offset by growth
in foam, construction, compounds, packaging and cardboard markets.

We are focused on high value segments within the SBR business, as well as driving network efficiencies, which
will enable us to mitigate the effects of these sector tailwinds. We have the largest market share in Europe with
37% of the market as of 2023. Our nearest competitors are Trinseo and BASF, which have 25% and 18%,
respectively, of the SBR market in Europe as of 2023 according to Kline and internal company estimates.

Overall the growth rate of the global market for SBRs is expected to be a CAGR of approximately 1.9% per
annum from 2022 to 2026.

**_Performance Materials (Chemical additives and non-aqueous based chemistry)_**

Performance materials include several smaller niche performance materials businesses focused on markets
including paper, carpet, acrylate monomers, specialty vinyl polymers, elastomeric modifiers and inorganic
specialties. While these are attractive businesses where we have leadership positions, they have been assessed as
non-core to the wider Group strategy.

Our broad range of performance materials enable existing technologies to move up to the next level by improving
materials processability, decreasing carbon emissions and electricity consumption in the value chain, improving
recyclability of materials, reducing waste, or by helping customers creating light-weight materials. These
materials are used in high performance markets such as the automotive sector, PVC manufacturing, construction
and polymer manufacturing.

**BUSINESS**

**Overview**

We are a high-performance, highly specialized polymers and ingredients company with strong geographic
diversity and product differentiation focused on a wide range of markets through our three end-customer facing
divisions: coatings and construction; adhesives; and health and protection. Speciality chemicals are value-add
products manufactured using polymerization and other reactive processes to transform commodity raw materials
into polymers and other complex chemical outputs that are used by customers in a variety of downstream
industries including the healthcare, consumer goods and construction sectors. End products for our speciality
chemicals include, but are not limited to, medical gloves, tires and rubber modifiers, artificial turf and carpet
backing, mattresses, food packaging, coatings and adhesives. We had revenue from continuing operations of
£1,970.9 million and EBITDA of £142.1 million from continuing operations for the year ended December 31,

**_Attractive end markets aligned to long term growth megatrends_**

While the level of demand for each of our product types and in each of our end markets is affected by factors
specific to that product type and that particular end market, certain overarching global trends have an impact
across our product types and end markets. These include (i) accelerating urbanization resulting in migration from
urban areas to cities and an increase in infrastructure developments, (ii) demographic changes and social changes,
such as an ageing population and a growing middle class in certain emerging markets, (iii) increased focus on
climate change and sustainability, including the impact of an increasing global focus on energy reduction and
more sustainable products, which in turn increases demand for lower carbon products more circular products as
well as adaptive products for a wider variety of weather conditions and (iv) a shifting economic center of gravity
toward Asia.

We believe that these global macroeconomic trends, when combined with specific growth drivers within each of
our end markets and the nuanced strategic initiatives within each of our three divisions, contribute to the expected
growth of our business in excess of GDP.

_Coatings & Construction Solutions_

We expect both of the coating and construction end markets we serve from our Coatings & Construction Solutions
division to grow in excess of global GDP, as our focused strategy allows us to access end-markets growing in
excess of global GDP, supported by specific end-market growth drivers. Within the coating end market, we see
both an increased customer appetite for water-based coatings that replace or remove the need for harmful organic
solvents as well as revenue synergies derived from our previous acquisitions. Within the construction end market,
favorable global macroeconomic trends, such as increased urbanization and a growing middle class within urban
areas, as well as the professionalization of the construction business are driving long-term increases in demand
for our products. Further, this increase in demand is augmented by a healthy innovation pipeline of new products
to provide a wide range of solutions for our customers.

We aim to leverage these growth drivers as part of our division-wide strategy to (i) improve our geographical
balance by focusing on growing markets in Asia and the Americas, (ii) optimize our asset base and expand network
efficiency projects, (iii) improve our product portfolio through more sustainable innovation derived from our

**_Global manufacturing footprint with further simplification of asset base underway_**

We have a global manufacturing footprint utilizing state-of-the-art technology underpinned by our long-term

An increasing focus on sustainability is a key trend that, we believe, will increase customer demand as regulation

Our “Vision 2030” plan is a longterm, embedded part of our business strategy, which we expect to be a value driver and a key principle in our

We have developed a well-balanced and diversified portfolio through a combination of organic and inorganic

activity, which helps to make our revenue more resilient to negative fluctuations in the demand for any particular
product or from any specific customer or geography. As we grow and capitalize on the underlying macroeconomic
trends in the speciality chemical industry, we have a clear path to increasing our product mix towards speciality
chemicals as we balance the geographic distribution of our end markets and streamline operations. A diverse
portfolio lends itself toward an increasing focus on high-value specialty chemical products for attractive and
resilient niche markets characterized by growth in excess of GDP.

weighting in the future. Our focus on the key value drivers for the speciality chemical market, including high

States while maintaining our presence in Asia, such that approximately 40% of our revenues are from EMEA,

**_Well-established financial policy with clear plan underway to further deleverage._**

We aim to maintain a conservative and sustainable capital management strategy with clear policies with respect
to our balance sheet leverage, and investments and shareholder returns in order to maintain an efficient and flexible
capital structure over a longer term. We take a disciplined approach to investment opportunities including mergers
and acquisitions and growth capital expenditure.

While our ambition historically has been to maintain a net leverage to EBITDA ratio, on an ongoing basis, of
approximately 1.0–2.0x, which we view as sustainable, our leverage is currently at higher than average levels,
due primarily to historically low NBR prices and demand as a result of destocking following the COVID-19
pandemic, combined with increased debt taken on to finance the acquisition of the Adhesive Resins Business.

We have responded to this challenge and in October 2023, completed a £276 million rights issue (net proceeds of
£266 million), demonstrating our commitment to reducing our leverage alongside other targeted actions,
including:

  - _Dividend suspension: In October 2022, we announced the suspension of all dividends for the year ended_
December 31, 2023 and an ongoing suspension until our net leverage is at least below 3.0x.

  - _Non-core divestment: The divestment of our Laminates, Films and Coated Fabrics Business on February_
28, 2023 raised net cash proceeds of $262 million (with a further $5 million receivable in cash on the
13-month anniversary of completion), while supporting our ongoing drive to increase the speciality
weighting of the Group. Our non-core portfolio rationalization program remains ongoing, with three
further formal divestment processes currently underway.

  - _Cost savings: We reduced our capital expenditures in 2023 to £84 million (£91 million in 2022) and have_
deployed a discretionary cost-savings program that successfully saved the Group £18 million in 2023,
further targeting savings of £30-40 million annually from our new procurement program and
approximately £20 million from our Adhesive Solutions program over 2024 and 2025.

  - _Working capital improvements: We identified opportunities to optimize working capital, in particular for_
our Adhesives Solutions business, with an overall reduction in inventory of £46 million in 2023. In
addition, we instituted a receivables financing program, with a £27.9 million increase in receivables
financing to £110.6 million.

**Our Strategy**

Our growth strategy is driven by global megatrends and we are focused on driving sustainable growth through
business efficiency, R&D and capital investment projects. Our strategy is composed of the following key pillars:

**_Organic growth in attractive end markets_**

Our core strategic growth markets, comprising coatings, construction, adhesives, and health and protection, each
benefit from robust sectoral growth dynamics in excess of baseline GDP. These markets are driven by accelerating
global megatrends including accelerating urbanization, demographic and social change, climate change and
sustainability and shifting economic power. In October 2022, as part of its new strategy, we announced a new
divisional organizational structure aligning our organization with our core end-markets. This alignment of
operational segments and end-markets is expected to assist us in anticipating and meeting customers’ needs at
pace and deliver better products with improved margin and product differentiation.

Innovation and more sustainable products, such as water-based solutions displacing solvents in the construction,
coatings and adhesives markets, are key drivers of growth across the Group’s core markets and developing
products through focused customer-centric R&D is a key component of the Group’s strategy. For the year ended
December 31, 2023, 22% of our sales volumes were derived from products that we launched in the previous five
years or are protected by patent or other intellectual property protections. In the year ended December 31, 2023,
we launched 14 new products across multiple application areas.

98


-----

**_Rigorous and consistent portfolio management to build focused, leading positions_**

As part of focusing the business, we intend to increase the weighting of speciality chemicals versus base chemicals
in our portfolio, create a more balanced geographic footprint, streamline our operations and apply more efficient
capital allocation across our businesses. During our strategic review in 2022, we identified our core markets,
which combine the most attractive growth prospects and where we are most differentiated. We are focusing our
resources on these segments and our new divisional structure enables differentiated steering in the allocation of
financial and operational resources in line with this strategy.

In addition, we identified a number of non-core businesses which have limited synergies with the rest our
identified growth platforms and which are less attractive areas for us to deploy capital. In line with our strategy,
on February 28, 2023, we completed the divestment of the Laminates, Films and Coated Fabrics Businesses.
Moving forward, we will continue to assess our strategic position in terms of disposing of non-core businesses to
rationalize our portfolio, reduce complexity and increase our focus on attractive end-markets and speciality
products.

Our divisional structure enables a differentiated steering of the allocation of financial and operational resources,
including capital allocation. We aim to allocate approximately 75% of our capital to the Coatings & Construction
Solutions and Adhesive Solutions divisions and approximately 25% to the Health & Protection and Performance
Materials division over the medium-term.

While our primary focus is on furthering our non-core divestment program, alongside this we are actively
considering a number of low-capital growth opportunities, such as potential partnerships. We are also identifying
potential accretive bolt-on acquisition opportunities in strategically attractive end markets and geographies for the
future, when our financial circumstances allow.

**_Operational and commercial excellence in how we run our business_**

We are focused on continuous improvement across our operations to advance production efficiency, sales
effectiveness and functional excellence while remaining committed to our sustainability standards. To achieve
these aims, we seek to identify good practice in all areas of the business and ensure that relevant learnings are
disseminated across the business.

We aim to drive profitability through maximizing the utilization of our assets. To achieve this, we focus on
identifying the root causes of production bottlenecks and finding innovative solutions. For example, a project at
our Longview site in Texas will debottleneck production and is expected to increase capacity by 10% to take
advantage of growth in the amorphous polyolefin market in North America.

For decades, we have been a world leading supplier of water-based polymers that avoid the use of solvents and
keep harmful VOCs out of the atmosphere. We have also become a global innovator in driving the use of waterbased technology. Over the last few years, we have worked to embed environmental sustainability into our
products and operations while remaining committed to driving efficiency. Sustainability now plays a major role
in our innovation agenda for customers, as well as our ongoing work to address our own greenhouse gas emission
footprint, as measured by our _“Vision 2030” roadmap and near-term milestone targets, as overseen by the_
Executive Sustainability Steering Committee established in 2022.

**_Diversity, equity and inclusion and holistic people development_**

Across all of our businesses, our employees execute our strategy and deliver for all stakeholders and we continue
to develop them to be prepared for the opportunities and challenges that lie ahead. To support this, we are
implementing four strategic employee priorities: (i) promoting holistic people development; (ii) strengthening our
leadership capability; (iii) embracing Synthomer excellence; and (iv) establishing an innovative workplace
culture.

**Our History**

Our history can be traced back to 1863 to the founding of George Yule & Co., the predecessor of the Group, in
London. The Company was initially incorporated and registered in England and Wales with the name Malaya

99


-----

General Company Limited on June 16, 1908 as a private company limited by shares with registered number
00098381. The Company’s name was subsequently changed to Yule Catto & Co. Limited on September 16, 1971,
and on October 14, 1971, was listed on the London Stock Exchange.

By 1980, the Company was engaged in the operation of marinas, rubber and oil palm plantations, and had
investments in oil exploration. In that year, we acquired Revertex Chemicals Limited, an international group
engaged in the processing of natural rubber latex and the manufacture of synthetic rubber lattices, resins and
emulsions. In 1981, the Company changed its name to Yule Catto & Co. plc.

In 1998, the Company acquired Holliday Chemical Holdings plc, a manufacturer of a wide range of chemicals,
including active pharmaceutical chemicals, pigments, dyes and metal salt compounds. From 2006 to 2008, we
disposed a range of businesses to become a focused supplier of water-based polymers. In 2011, we acquired
PolymerLatex GmbH, headquartered in Marl, Germany, with operations in Europe and Asia, a manufacturer of
speciality polymers including SBR and NBR lattices and a range of acrylic dispersions.

In 2012, the Company changed its name to Synthomer plc, and in 2016, we completed the acquisition of PAC
from Hexion Inc. and sold Revertex South Africa (Pty.) Limited. In 2017, we acquired all of the issued share
capital of Speciality Additives, a niche performance additives business serving the decorative and industrial
coatings industries while in 2018 it acquired BASF Pischelsdorf. On April 1, 2020, we acquired OMNOVA, a
leading developer and manufacturer of emulsion polymers, speciality chemicals and decorative products. On April
1, 2022 we completed the acquisition of the Adhesive Resins Business, which develops, manufactures and sells
resins and polymers for adhesive products.

In February 2023, we completed the divestment of our Laminates, Films and Coated Fabrics Businesses (which
included business lines previously acquired in the OMNOVA acquisition) to Surteco North America, Inc.

**Our Products**

We operate in the speciality chemicals stage of the chemicals value chain, which involves taking raw material
inputs and building complex chemical outputs utilized by customers in a variety of end products and downstream
industries.

Speciality chemicals are value-add products manufactured using polymerization and other reactive processes to
transform commodity raw materials into complex polymer chemicals. Speciality chemicals are then utilized in a
wide variety of downstream end-markets, including the healthcare, consumer goods and construction markets.
Some of the end-uses for speciality chemicals include, but are not limited to, medical gloves and fabric supported
gloves, coated paper and carpet backing, foams for mattresses and pillows, adhesives and cement modifiers.

We primarily produce water-based polymers through an emulsion polymerization process, which removes the
requirement for large amounts of organic solvents during production and use. These polymers are made up of
different chemical building blocks, or monomers, that lead to the different chemistry platforms in our portfolio.
The resultant water-based polymers have very low levels of VOCs, some of which can have harmful effects from
a health and wider environmental impact.

100


-----

We believe that we offer the widest range of chemistry platforms available in the market, and our product
development processes enable us to deliver the best value solutions to customers across the various types of
chemicals we offer. Our innovation model leverages our expertise across core chemistries and applications to
effectively deploy our core know-how in into a diverse portfolio of end-uses. For example, chemistry solutions
initially focused on improving the coating performance of water-based paints have been adapted to give enhanced
performance in nitrile glove applications, while other coatings products have been applied into oil and gas drilling
uses. Products which were originally developed for paper coating have been modified for use as a binder for the
anode of lithium batteries, opening a new growth market. Other polymers developed for use in paper have also
been introduced to modify cement admixtures to improve workability, flexibility and mechanical strength of a
construction mortar.

The growth drivers of each of our product types across end-markets and geographic regions are supported by
accelerating urbanization, demographic and social change, climate change and sustainability and shifting
economic power mega-trends. Due to a balanced product mix and global asset footprint, with exposure to both
emerging and developed markets, we believe that we are well placed to capture market growth.

**_Our Divisions_**

With effect from January 1, 2023, we implemented a new organizational structure, comprising three global
divisions through which the different product categories are developed and produced: (i) Coatings & Construction
Solutions; (ii) Adhesive Solutions; and (iii) Health & Protection and Performance Materials.

Our speciality growth platforms (Coatings & Construction Solutions and Adhesive Solutions) benefit from robust
growth dynamics, have strong and stable leadership positions within their markets and offer products that are
distinct from our competitors. Across these platforms, we are actively looking to strengthen innovation and our
technological position, broaden our offering of core products and enter attractive new speciality niches while
maintaining disciplined capital allocation.

The Health & Protection platform benefits from the attractive growth dynamics of the underlying medical glove
market but is generally more cyclical. We are currently seeking to enhance this platform through organic means
only, supported by expected sector growth in excess of global GDP.

Performance Materials are the non-core elements of our portfolio and include legacy non-core businesses from
the Performance Elastomer and Industrial Specialities divisions. This used to include the Laminates, Films and
Coated Fabrics Businesses, but these were sold to Surteco North America Inc. in a sale which completed on
February 28, 2023 for a total net proceeds of $269 million.

The divisions have a clear end-market focus:

   - **Coatings & Construction Solutions: speciality coatings, construction, fiber bonding, foam, energy,**

speciality additives.

   - **Adhesive Solutions: tires, hygiene, packaging, tapes and labels.**

   - **Health & Protection and Performance Materials: gloves, speciality paper coatings and carpet backing.**

101


-----

_Coatings & Construction Solutions_

The Coatings & Construction Solutions division brings together a number of our prior business segments to focus
on end-markets where we have leadership positions and potential for growth. For the year ended December 31,
2023, the Coatings & Construction Solutions division generated revenue of £815.5 million (representing 41.4%
of revenue from continuing operations), EBITDA of £100.1 million (representing EBITDA margin of 12.3% from
continuing operations) and underlying operating profit of £73.3 million. The Coatings & Construction division
has approximately 2,100 employees across 18 manufacturing sites.

The Coatings & Construction Solutions division serves a diverse range of sectors and customers within its target
end-markets, with a focus on architectural and masonry coatings (27% of the division’s revenue from continuing
operations for the year ended December 31, 2023), consumer materials (24% of the division’s revenue from
continuing operations for the year ended December 31, 2023), construction (21% of the division’s revenue from
continuing operations for the year ended December 31, 2023), industrial coatings (16% of the division’s revenue
from continuing operations for the year ended December 31, 2023) and energy solutions (12% of the division’s
revenue from continuing operations for the year ended December 31, 2023).

Our Coatings & Construction Solutions division leverages our competitive advantage gained by the sustainability
benefits of water-based technologies in applications such as architectural coatings, coatings for wood and metal,
and automotive coatings. We also have strengths in the energy sector, where our advanced liquid and dry
cementing products as well as our high-performance drilling fluid additives are used in challenging operational
environments around the world (covering conventional and unconventional drilling and completion
requirements). In addition, we produce water-based anode binders, most notably SBR, that help deliver high
charge capacity, reliability and long life in lithium-ion batteries for electric vehicles, energy storage and other
devices – supporting the transition to a decarbonized world. The key chemistries and product markets captured
by the activities of this division are set out below.

_(i)  Aqueous (acrylic and vinylic based) dispersions_

Dispersions products are sold predominantly to paint and coatings manufacturers and formulators of adhesives
and construction products with exposure to globally growing market segments. Strong application know-how is
required to support this commercial offering, as this market is characterized by innovation and the development
of bespoke solutions for customers. We benefit from this dynamic due to our longstanding customer relationships
reinforced by the high supplier switching costs for our customers.

There are continued significant regulatory drivers that support water-based technologies across end-markets, since
water-based products tend to have lower levels of VOCs than solvent-based products. There is a general trend in
the industry towards producing more sustainable products including the elimination of VOCs from coatings and
adhesives formulations, since VOCs can contribute to climate change and have unfavorable toxicological and

102


-----

odor characteristics. Acrylic, styrene-acrylic and vinyl dispersions contain significantly lower levels of VOCs
than solvent borne coatings formulations.

Our range of acrylic dispersions include products used in emulsion surface coatings, primers, interior and exterior
wood varnishes, floor paints and roof coatings. Our range of styrene-acrylic dispersions include products used in
interior and exterior emulsion paints and roof coatings and also has applications in packaging adhesives. Our
range of vinyl acetate dispersions includes products used in interior and exterior emulsion coatings and adhesives
for packaging, tiles and wood as well as sealants for construction applications.

We are the second largest producer in a fragmented landscape of acrylic and vinylic dispersions in Europe and
the Middle East by revenue and volume. Globally, we expect the market growth for acrylics dispersions to be
approximately 3% per annum from 2022 to 2026 according to Kline.

We believe that our position as a leading producer of water-based dispersions is supported by regulatory drivers,
since our water-based products remove the requirement to use harmful organic solvents in manufacture and use,
thus reducing environmental burden and potential health impacts. For the year ended December 31, 2023, the
Group sold 286 kilotonnes of dispersions products, constituting 22% of the Group’s revenues. For the year ended
December 31, 2023, sales of our dispersions products comprised a significant portion of the of our Coatings &
Construction Solutions division, in addition to a material portion of our Adhesive Solutions division. See “—
_Adhesive Solutions.”_

We produce dispersions at the Group’s manufacturing facilities in the US, Germany, Italy, Spain, France, the UK,
the Czech Republic, Malaysia, Vietnam, Portugal and Saudi Arabia.

_(ii)  SBR latex_

SBR latex polymers are water-based synthetic polymers that are manufactured by a process called emulsion
polymerization. SBR latex is sold primarily to the speciality segments of the paper, construction, technical textile
and floor coverings markets, as well as adhesives and foams.

Latex foam, a high solid SBR, is mainly used in mattresses, pillows and manifold cushioning materials, with the
entire spectrum of this varied product largely addressed through the use of different high solid SBR grades, in
order to apply different degrees of firmness and elasticity to these products to suit consumer’s needs. Other
applications include uses in footwear, such as for inner soles. As part of our ongoing reorganization and
optimization efforts, in January 2024, we transferred our foam business to the Health & Protection and
Performance Materials division, and will be presented as such going forward.

We are the leading producer of High Solid & Carboxylated SBR in Europe by volume. The products have excellent
properties as binders in multiple industrial end-uses. We primarily produce SBR to be used in coated paper and
packaging; carpet backing; foam markets for use in mattresses, pillows and shoes; cement mortar; insulation
systems; waterproofing; and diaper components.

Our manufacturing centers for SBR products utilize our advanced manufacturing technology and are closely
integrated with our key raw material suppliers to ensure security of our raw material supply. In turn, our
manufacturing centers are also typically located close to our core customer base in order to support our customers’
logistical requirements. We produce SBR at our manufacturing facilities in Germany, Austria, Italy, the US and
China, with additional sites in the Netherlands and Egypt. We are continually evaluating and developing our
product offerings in order to meet customer needs and our SBR products have recently been used in a wide range
of products that support the energy transition.

We are focused on high value segments within our SBR business, as well as driving network efficiencies, which
we expect will enable us to mitigate the effects of these sector headwinds. We have a strong market position in
Europe.

For the year ended December 31, 2023, we sold approximately 360 kilotonnes of SBR products constituting 19%
of the Group’s revenues. In the near-to-medium term, we expect growth in construction facing end-markets, with
a slight decline in the graphic paper market as customers continue to move to electronic media. We are also
continuing business development in high value applications of SBR, including oil fields and batteries. For the
years ended December 31, 2022 and 2021, sales of our SBR products were primarily accounted for as part of our
Performance Elastomers segment and also accounted for a material amount of our Functional Solutions segment.

For the year ended December 31, 2023, SBR products comprised a material portion of each our Coatings &

_Adhesive Solutions_

The Adhesive Solutions division, which represented 29.5% of our revenue from continuing operations in 2023
(excluding inter-segmental revenue), is largely the successor of our former Adhesive Technologies segment, but
also includes elements of our former Functional Solutions and Industrial Specialties divisions. For the year ended
December 31, 2023, the Adhesive Solutions division generated revenue from continuing operations of £581.7
million, EBITDA of £31.2 million (representing EBITDA margin of 5.4%), and an underlying operating loss of
£7.5 million from continuing operations. The Adhesive Solutions division has over 700 employees across 6 plants
across North America, Europe and Asia.

The Adhesive Solutions division serves a diverse range of sectors and customers, with a focus on tapes and labels
(27% of the division’s revenue in the year ended December 31, 2023), plastic modification (16% of the division’s
revenue in the year ended December 31, 2023), packaging (15% of the division’s revenue in the year ended
December 31, 2023), tires (13% of the division’s revenue in the year ended December 31, 2023) and hygiene
(12% of the division’s revenue in the year ended December 31, 2023). Other product markets comprise the
remaining 17% of the Adhesive Solutions division’s revenue in the year ended December 31, 2023.

With six manufacturing sites across North America, Europe and Asia, and access to multiple sites of other
divisions, the Adhesive Solutions division has leading positions across all tackifier markets in an addressable
market of approximately $12 billion and one of the broadest offerings in the industry in terms of number of
products. Much of the division is formed from our purchase of the Adhesive Resins Business, which was
completed on April 1, 2022. We believe that adhesives is an attractive growth market, in which we are able to
offer a differentiated and diversified platform tailored to the needs of our customers and strong R&D and technical
capabilities. Our offering includes a large and growing portfolio of products in the tapes and labels, hygiene,
packaging, plastics and high-performance tire additives markets. For example, in 2023, we had two significant
product launches, including Plextol XA 2565, which allows tape manufacturers to achieve the adhesive
performance level of solvent-based adhesives with a water base, and Plastvance TR&E, which allows for reducing
the thickness of plastic packaging, and designing flexible and rigid packaging from only one recyclable material.
In addition, in 2022, we launched our amorphous poly-olefin (“APO”) polymer, the Aerafin 230, which allows
carmakers to formulate hot melt laminating adhesives for automotive interior applications, replacing Polyurethane
reactive adhesives (“PUR”). Aerafin-based adhesives eliminate the use of isocyanate crosslinkers that have to be
used with the PUR, a substance that is increasingly regulated. In the area of automotive sustainability, we also
developed a new modified silane resin which helps a tire making customer improve wet and dry grip for tires
while reducing rolling resistance, improving fuel efficiency.

The Adhesive Solutions division also offers increased specialization and attractive EBITDA margins, while
supporting our sustainability goals by offering renewable products and circularity options. This is supported by a
strong and embedded customer base of over 700 customers in more than 1,000 locations across the world.

The key chemistries and product markets captured by the activities of this division are set out below.

_(i)  Adhesive resins and polymers_

Adhesive, or tackifying, resins are key adhesive components providing tack and adhesion made from
hydrocarbons or pine chemicals. They are mixed with polymers for hot melt adhesives used in hygiene adhesives,
packaging, tapes and labels, and for modification of rubber and plastics. We develop, manufacture and sell
tackifying resins for adhesive products, for uses in end-markets such as packaging, hygiene and high-performance
tire additives. The majority of the tackifying resins for adhesive products that we produce are developed and
manufactured at sites that were acquired as part of the acquisition of the Adhesives Resins Business. For the years
ended December 31, 2021 and 2022, sales of tackifying resins, polymers and additives for adhesive products were
accounted for as part of our Adhesive Technologies segment, and for the year ended December 31, 2023,
comprised the significant majority of our Adhesive Solutions division. For the year ended December 31, 2023,
we sold approximately 174 kilotonnes of adhesive products constituting 22.2% of the Group’s revenues.

104


-----

The global tackifying resins market in 2023 was estimated to be approximately 3.1 megatonnes, of which
approximately 62% consists of hydrocarbon resins. Hydrocarbon-based tackifiers based on C5 and C9 cracker byproduct streams are experiencing a solid market share in most applications due to pricing, stability, and
availability, with overall market demand for hydrocarbon tackifying resins estimated to grow in line with global
GDP growth. We maintain a strong market share within the global hydrocarbon resins market.

Pure Monomer Resins (“PMRs”) are used for hot melt adhesives in packaging and hygiene due to their tack
properties, but the largest market today is in rubber modification for tires and thermoplastic elastomer compounds.
PMRs are used as an additive in tire treads to improve performance, and demand for high performance tires is
growing as governments impose more stringent performance regulations, and electrical vehicles are growing.
Overall, we expect the global market for PMRs will grow in excess of global GDP. We have the leading position
within the global PMR market.

Speciality rosin resins are natural tackifying resins based on stabilized gum rosin harvested from living trees. With
a wide range of characteristics, rosin resins are used to provide adhesion to the final product, with main endmarkets being tapes, coatings, hot melt adhesives, food and beverage, tires and electronics. Overall, we expect the
global market for speciality rosins will grow in excess of global GDP. While our market share within the overall
global rosins market is small, we are amongst the top three businesses capturing market share in the more highly
specialized hydrogenated rosins market.

APOs have three main applications: hot melt adhesives (packaging, hygiene, building and construction and
automotive end-markets); rheology modification (bitumen roofing and road markings); and sealing (windows and
cables used in construction). APO demand was approximately 150 kilotonnes in 2023, with hygiene being the
largest segment and expected to grow the fastest. Overall, the growth rate of the global market for APOs is
expected to be approximately 3-4% per annum from 2022 to 2027. We are amongst the top three businesses
capturing market share within the global APO market.

_(ii)  Adhesive emulsions_

The second family of polymers we produce for application in the adhesives and sealants industry are adhesive
emulsions, which are part of the water-based dispersions category of product described above. Adhesive
emulsions are mainly pure acrylics or vinylics, and Emulsion polymers are primarily used for PSAs and release
coatings for the tape and label market, as well as polymeric binders for caulks and sealants. In June 2016, we
acquired PAC, which also gave us access to acrylic platforms in the PSA market. We project that pressure sensitive
tapes and label markets will both grow consistent with global GDP. We have a strong market share with respect
to water-based PSA, with clear differentiation from competitors.

_(iii)  Lithene polybutadiene_

The third polymer family serving the adhesives and sealants market are liquid polybutadiene polymers, including
LITHENE[TM]. Liquid polybutadiene polymers are used as modifiers in vulcanized rubber systems, and particularly
in sound dampening, bonding and sealing applications. We expect the market for liquid polybutadienes will grow
in excess of global GDP. We are among the top three businesses capturing market share within the liquid
polybutadiene market.

_Health & Protection and Performance Materials_

The Health & Protection and Performance Materials division, which represented 29.1% of our revenue from
continuing operations in 2023, combines the Health & Protection product portfolio (comprised mainly of NBR)
with the Performance Materials product portfolio (which includes SBR, chemical additives and non-aqueous
based chemistry products). For the year ended December 31, 2023, the Health & Protection and Performance
Materials division generated revenue from continuing operations of £573.7 million, EBITDA of £31.0 million
(representing an EBITDA margin of 5.4%, and an underlying operating loss of £0.7 million from continuing
operations). The Health & Protection and Performance Materials division has 1,300 employees across 12 plants.

The Health & Protection and Performance Materials division serves a diverse range of sectors and customers,
with a focus on health & protection (24% of the division’s revenue in the year ended December 31, 2023), paper
(14% of the division’s revenue in the year ended December 31, 2023), rubber and plastic additives (17% of the
division’s revenue in the year ended December 31, 2023), acrylic monomers (14% of the division’s revenue in
the year ended December 31, 2023), carpet (14% of the division’s revenue in the year ended December 31, 2023)

105


-----

and compounds (8% of the division’s revenue in the year ended December 31, 2023). The remaining 9% of
revenue comes from sales to William Blythe Limited, a speciality chemical solutions company based in the UK.
In January 2024, the majority of our rubber and plastic additives businesses moved from the Health & Protection
and Performance Materials division to Coatings & Construction Solutions, while we transferred our foam business
from our Coatings & Construction Solutions division to the Health & Protection and Performance Materials
division.

The Health & Protection and Performance Materials division enhances protection and performance in a wide
range of industries, including medical glove manufacture, speciality paper, food packaging, carpet and artificial
turf and gel foam elastomers. We are a global leader in the NBR market, which our healthcare, food preparation
and hospitality customers use for glove dipping. The growth in urbanization and healthcare in emerging markets
is a particular opportunity. Around 400 billion gloves are used each year globally, but these are disproportionately
used in developed markets. Per capita use in the USA is 200 compared to 100 in Europe, and much lower in
developing regions. We believe that gap will close over time. While the NBR market can be volatile, it is a $2,000
million addressable market as of 2023, and we believe it is set to continue to grow due to the above market trends.

Health & Protection is the largest part of the Health & Protection and Performance Materials division, but we
operate a number of smaller, niche businesses under Performance Materials which focus on markets including
paper, carpet, acrylate monomers, speciality vinyl polymers, elastomeric modifiers and inorganic specialities.
While these are attractive businesses where we have leadership positions, we believe them to be non-core to our
wider strategy.

The key chemistries and product markets captured by the activities of this division are set out below.

_(i)  NBR latex_

NBR latex polymers are water-based synthetic polymers that are manufactured by an emulsion polymerization
process. The products have excellent barrier and tear-resistance properties and are resistant to oils and chemicals.
As NBR products do not contain the proteins which occur in natural rubber, they can also offer a hypoallergenic
alternative to natural rubber.

NBR latex products are used in the manufacture of dipped products for medical, industrial and household
applications, the largest being protective gloves. We offer a range of NBR products for use primarily in the health
and protection end-markets for use in the manufacture of thin-walled gloves for medical and laboratory use and
heavy-duty gloves for household and industrial applications. NBR latex products are sold globally to gloves
manufacturers, including both large diversified medical and consumer goods companies and smaller niche
manufacturers.

Globally, we are the second largest producer of NBR latex by volume. We have also made significant R&D
investment in NBR products in recent years which have driven our development of market leading products. Our
NBR products serve a fast-growing market which is expected to grow at a rate in excess of 6% during the coming
years. We have expanded our manufacturing capacity of NBR products in recent years, including a 60,000 tonne
per year capacity expansion at our existing manufacturing site in Pasir Gudang, Malaysia, during 2022. The Pasir
Gudang facility is the largest NBR manufacturer in Malaysia. In August 2023, we took the decision to mothball
our NBR facility in Kluang, Malaysia, which is expected to reduce our NBR manufacturing capacity by
approximately 20%, and support better utilization levels across the Group.

Our position as a supplier of NBR products is further strengthened by our geographic proximity to major glove
producers. We focus on NBR production primarily in Southeast Asia. In Europe, NBR is produced at our
manufacturing facility in Italy. For the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2022, sales of our NBR products were
primarily accounted for as part of our Performance Elastomers segment, and for the year ended December 31,
2023, comprise a significant portion of our Health & Protection and Performance Materials division.

Further, NBR latex competes with Polyvinyl Chloride (“PVC”) and natural rubber in this market. NBR is expected
to continue to gain share over PVC and natural rubber with estimated growth of 6%+ CAGR according to the
Malaysian Rubber Glove Manufacturers Association over the coming years. Asia is expected to remain the hub
for gloves with over 80% of global production and major investments in manufacturing capacity, even with Europe
and North America investments accelerating supported by government incentives to secure local supply.

106


-----

The exceptional global demand for NBR gloves during the COVID-19 pandemic resulted in a record performance
for Performance Elastomers in 2021. After 2021, destocking of nitrile gloves caused substantial softening of
demand, resulting in lower NBR volumes in 2022. While underlying end customer demand for medical gloves
remains has remained similar to pre-COVID-19 levels for the past two years, the current divergence between
capacity and demand for NBR has been slowly abating, with volumes modestly improving in the third and fourth
quarters of 2023, although with low unit profit margins persisting. The following figure illustrates signs of abating
destocking across certain of our key customers.

The outlook for underlying demand remains in line with strong growth due to the hygiene megatrend and growth
in use of emerging markets. The business is well positioned to capture this long-term opportunity.

Our goal is to now grow sales into higher margin customer segments by offering best in class technical support,
leveraging long-term contracts and continuing to invest in innovation, with the Asia Innovation Centre as the
center of excellence for global glove innovation.

_(ii)  SBR latex_

The Health & Protection and Performance Materials division is also involved in the production of SBR latex,
particularly with respect to the production of speciality paper coatings and carpet backing. Our overall production
of SBR latex is described in greater detail above.

_(iii)  Specialties_

We produce polymers and speciality chemicals that are used in high performance markets such as the automotive
sector, PVC manufacturing, construction and polymer manufacturing. We have a highly diversified technology
base for speciality products which enables us to serve a range of high-performance applications segments. We are
a leading supplier of suspending agents used in the production of PVC with ALCOTEX[TM] polyvinyl alcohols.
Other applications include catalysts and flame retardants and a range of high-performance coating additives.

Specialities are used as key formulating components in certain of our core markets which allow us to cross-sell
our speciality products to existing customers. For example, certain of our specialities products are used to enhance
the performance of decorative and industrial paints, which is one of the core end-markets served by our dispersions
business. Our long-standing customer relationships enable us to develop bespoke solutions for our customers.

For the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2022, sales of our specialities products were primarily accounted for
as part of our Industrial Specialties division, and for the year ended December 31, 2023, are included in our Health
& Protection and Performance Materials division and also our Coatings & Construction Solutions divisions.

For the year ended December 31, 2023, we sold 44 kilotonnes of industrial specialities products and derived 8%
of revenues from continuing operations from sales of industrial specialities products. We hold leading positions
in select niche specialities markets globally. Demand for more sustainable products, adoption of more sustainable
manufacturing practices by manufacturers, and emissions regulations provide our specialities businesses with

107


-----

opportunities for growth. For example, our powder coatings business, which manufactures solvent free products,
is well suited to grow due to demand from environmentally conscious customers.

We produce speciality polymers at our manufacturing facilities in the UK, Italy and Belgium.

_(iv)  Polymer modifiers_

Consisting of elastomeric modifiers and reinforcing resins, our polymer modifiers are used in a wide range of
plastic and rubber components, across an array of end-uses including automotive, wire and cable, belts and hoses,
construction, hose and tubing and footwear. In these product markets our expertise in NBR, SBR and acrylic
polymers have been applied to create solid, powder products to enable mixing with base polymers including
polyolefins, thermoplastic urethanes (“TPUs”), engineering thermoplastics, rubber and PVC to enhance
properties such as flexibility, toughness, durability and aesthetics. Because of the complex nature of the products,
the resulting performance of the end product is differentiated, typically higher value, and difficult for competitors
to replicate.

In some applications our polymer modifiers allow plastics and rubber producers to increase the performance and
value of lower cost polymers by making them more flexible, softer, lower gloss, or more durable. Other
applications include use in high value, engineering thermoplastics, such as polyacetal or TPUs to modify and
toughen them for specific application needs. These products also improve the processability of many polymer
systems, offering polymer compounders improved manufacturing productivity.

For the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2022, sales of our polymer modifier products were primarily
accounted for as part of our Performance Elastomers segment, and for the year ended December 31, 2023,
comprise a portion of our Health & Protection and Performance Materials division. As of January, 1, 2024,
Polymer Modifiers are part of our Coatings & Construction Solutions division, and will be presented as such going
forward.

_(v)  Acrylate Monomers_

We produce all of our acrylate monomers from a single site at Sokolov, Czech Republic, which are in turn sold
externally to customers in European markets, as well as internally to our European Functional Solutions
dispersions business. While these are attractive businesses where we have leadership positions, we believe they
are non-core to our wider strategy.

For the year ended December 31, 2023, we sold approximately 52.1 kilotonnes of acrylate products. We are
continuing to review potential options for new products, as our site is ISCC+ certified, allowing us to procure
biorecycled feedstock for low carbon products. We are also exploring collaboration with potential partners on
developing new bio-based products which would support our customers in achieving their net zero aspirations.

For the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2022, sales of acrylate monomer products were accounted for as part
of our Acrylate Monomers segment, and for the year ended December 31, 2023, comprise part of our Health &
Protection and Performance Materials division.

**Customers And End Markets**

**_Customers_**

We have a diversified blue-chip customer base with long-term established relationships. For the year ended
December 31, 2023, we had approximately 6,000 customers worldwide. Our customer base has grown over time,
having increased by approximately 50% since 2019. For the year ended December 31, 2023, our largest customer
represented approximately 3.1% of total revenues from continuing operations while revenues from our twenty
largest customers represented 23.7% of total revenues from continuing operations. Across each of our global
operating divisions are products that are typically integral components of our customers’ end products, resulting
in high switching costs for existing customers.

We monitor global trends, including demographic and political and economic trends, as well as market
developments to anticipate and meet our customers’ needs. We aim to design our chemical formulations to ensure
they not only meet the requirements of our customers but also those of the end-users of our customers’ products.

108


-----

Our technical services teams work with customers to ensure that we are providing the right formulation for their
needs.

One example of our product penetration, brand recognition, and integration with customers’ supply chains is our
PMR product line within the Adhesive Solutions division. We are viewed in the global adhesive industry as a
trusted long-term partner and the market leading supplier of high-quality speciality resins used in multiple
applications from tire tread compounds to pressure sensitive adhesives and medical packaging. Our broad product
portfolio, innovation, global manufacturing network, technical support and proximity to customers supports our
leading position. We have a decades-long history of supplying PMR across the globe, and our recent related
product launches of highly purified PMR for direct food contact applications and of reactive PMRs for high
performance tires have further strengthen our relationship with our customers.

The majority of customer contracts are structured to enable pass-through of raw material costs, enabling us to
support stable and sustainable margins. A significant proportion of our customer contracts typically have no
pricing commitment beyond one month, allowing us to modify pricing in line with raw material costs. Our
products are generally priced in accordance with one of two different types of agreements: (i) formulaic
agreements with price-indexed clauses and/or ICIS-related pricing, which provide for a high degree of direct pass
through of any changes in raw material prices to customers; and (ii) agreements renegotiated on a regular (usually
monthly) basis, in which our ability to retain the benefits of declines in raw material prices or to pass through
increases in raw material prices is affected by the supply and demand balance of the particular product as well as
the ability to apply pricing and margin enhancement tools according to customer relationships and the expectations
customers have in respect of these costs. Accordingly, substantially all of our customer agreements have no pricing
commitment beyond one month or one fiscal quarter, with approximately one third of our customer agreements
being formulaic with the remainder being generally negotiable on a monthly basis. Thus, we are generally able to
maintain our unit margins even when prices for raw materials experience sudden or sharp increases, although
there is typically a one-month or three-month lag time in our ability to do so.

**_End Markets_**

The products we offer have applications in a range of end markets. Our product line consists of wide range of
speciality polymers which are used as the base component or as a performance enhancing ingredient in materials
such as coatings, adhesives, construction materials, rubber, and plastics. The majority of these products are waterbased systems which are produced and used without the need for volatile organic solvents. For example, we
produce the polymers which are the base material in water-based paints which replace less sustainable solventbased coatings. The balance of our product portfolio consists of resins and polymers which are “100% active” in
use, meaning they are used in applications such as hot melt adhesive without the need for solvents or water carriers.
In all, our products enable the elimination of the use of solvents, thus eliminating emissions of VOCs to the
environment, some of which can have harmful effects on human health and the environment.

In the year ended December 31, 2023, Coatings & Construction Solutions (with end-markets uses including
architectural and masonry coatings, mortar modification, waterproofing and flooring, fiber bonding, and energy
solutions) was our largest division, constituting 41.4% of revenues from continuing operations for the year ended
December 31, 2023. Over the same period, our Adhesive Solutions division (with end-markets uses including
tapes and labels, packaging, hygiene, tires and plastic modification) constituted 29.5% of our revenues from
continuing operations, while our Health & Protection and Performance Materials division (with end-markets uses
including medical glove manufacturing, speciality paper, food packaging, carpet and artificial turf and gel foam
elastomers and vinyl-coated seating fabrics) constituted 29.1% of revenues from continuing operations.

**New Product Innovation**

New product innovation is an important component of our strategy and plays a key role in the success of our
speciality business segments. Our product development lifecycle begins within our business units, focusing on
identifying opportunities within our end-markets. Our market segment teams take a market-driven approach to
identify new product opportunities based on megatrends, segment drivers and individual customer input. Our
Innovation Excellence Framework guides our innovation process based on six “pillars of excellence,” including:
(i) aligning innovation resources to the business strategy; (ii) fostering creativity within our team and through
collaborations; (iii) incorporating process safety and sustainability into product design (iv) investing in people,
working in teams; (v) delivering excellence in project and portfolio management; and (vi) focusing on delivering

109


-----

results. Through our Innovation Excellence Framework in 2023, we increased our focus on skills development,
further implemented advanced experimental design and modelling and increased utilization of artificial
intelligence methods.

Our work on new product design, process improvements, and new application development aims to deliver more
sustainable innovations and offer value-added performance to our customers, while driving growth. We apply the
three principles of our “Technology Platforms” approach, namely (i) sustainability, (ii) enhanced performance,
and (iii) formulation and process efficiency; while identifying innovation opportunities through market research
and collaborations with customers.

We measure our overall innovation results in line with two key targets: (i) of the percentage of sales coming from
new and protected products (“NPP”) (where a new product is defined as launched in the past five years and a
protected product is one covered by a patent), for which we are targeting a level of at least 20% over the long
term; and (ii) the percentage of products launched in the prior twelve months which have a defined sustainability
benefit, for which are targeting a level of at least 60% by 2030, in line with our “Vision 2030” plan ambitions. See
“—Environmental, Social and Governance.” We have achieved our target NPP performance in each of the past
three years, with scores of 24%, 20% and 22% of total sales volume in each of the years ended December 31,
2021, 2022 and 2023, respectively. Since establishing the sustainable innovation target in 2021, we have made
important progress towards our goal, with the proportion of new products launched with sustainability benefits
rising to 64% for the year ended December 31, 2023 up from 50% for the year ended December 31, 2022, and
43% in for the year ended December 31, 2021.

In addition to our dedicated innovation teams within our business divisions, a dedicated Group Sustainability and
Innovation function oversees our worldwide innovation network, conducts research on new technology platforms
and provides centralized support for safety management, material characterization, process development,
intellectual property and regulatory compliance. Our Group Sustainability and Innovation function works closely
with our divisional business and innovation directors to investigate new product and process technologies (such
as biobased polymer chemistry) and provide new technology platforms from which to develop new products and
improve the operation of our plants. Examples of new products emerging from this source of innovation include
polymers for battery systems, innovative multi-surface architectural coatings, more sustainable construction
materials and higher performing adhesives for applications ranging from hygiene products to durable goods such
as mattresses and automotive. In recent years, our Group Sustainability and Innovation function has placed
increased focus on driving new manufacturing processes to improve productivity while reducing greenhouse gas
emissions, waste generation and water consumption, as well as the use of low carbon raw material sources.

Our innovation programs are focused on improving our margins and enhancing product differentiation. One key
element of our innovation strategy centers on the evolution of existing products to new applications and providing
tailored solutions to our customers. When performance targets are beyond the range of existing products, we

110


-----

employ our expertise in polymer design and product formulation to tailor existing products and change their
performance in order to meet customers’ specific requirements. Our expertise in the applications of our products
helps to add further value to our customers’ use of those products, including by allowing our customers to meet
their own sustainability targets. We are also able to leverage our core applications and technology across multiple
platforms.

For example, we are developing a new chloroprene-free contact adhesive as a direct result of customer requests,
and we have announced our intent to eliminate an emulsifier used in fiber bonding binders called alkylphenol
ethoxylates (APEO) by the end of 2024. This significant undertaking involves reformulating 17 products, and
